headline: In College Football, No Player Escapes the Eye of the Strength Coach

Buildings stand sliced in half, wires and beds and bathtubs exposed, with families still living inside. headline: In Shinjuku, ‘Blade Runner’ in Real Life
abstract: Daido Moriyama’s images of Shinjuku are like being in “Blade Runner,” a futuristic place of phantoms, electric energy and tension.
lead_paragraph: When I walk in the evening with my camera from Kabuki-cho to Kuyakusho-dori and then along Okubo-dori toward Shin-Okubo Station, I sometimes feel a shiver running down my spine. I find myself flinching for some reason, even though nothing in particular has happened. Shadow-spirits squirm amid the darkness of the back streets, under the lights and neon signs. The sight line of the small camera in my hand picks up the sensitive reactions of these wraiths, like electrical impulses. As they perceive coarse tremors in the surrounding air, my cells quiver with tension. Wandering around, enveloped in the vaguely violent atmosphere, I persuade myself that it is my duty as a photographer to photograph Shinjuku without shrinking back.

headline: Review: ‘Harry Potter and the Cursed Child’ Explores the Power of Time
abstract: This book is the script of a production that just opened in London, and even though it lacks the play’s much-talked-about special effects, it is a stay-up-all-night read.

Rowling’s magical seven-volume Harry Potter series is the ultimate bildungsroman, tracing that young wizard’s coming of age, as he not only battles evil but also struggles to come to terms with the responsibilities, losses and burdens of adulthood. In the course of those books, we see a plucky schoolboy, torn by adolescent doubts and confusions, grow into an epic hero, kin to King Arthur, Luke Skywalker and Spider-Man.

headline: Cold-Brewed Coffee Without the Hourslong Wait
abstract: A new appliance promises a smooth cup in 10 minutes flat.
lead_paragraph: Cold-brewed coffee, for many the gold standard when it comes to a smooth-tasting cup, takes planning and time. Now the product developers at FirstBuild, a subsidiary of GE Appliances, have come up with the Prisma. The machine uses a vacuum infusion system to produce excellent cold-brewed coffee in a mere 10 minutes. The gadget has a handblown 23.7-ounce carafe and takes regular pleated-paper basket filters. But there’s still a wait as presale orders will not deliver for about a year: Prisma Cold Brew Coffee Maker, $240 (discounted from what will be the regular price of $299), indiegogo.com.

headline: A Hops Farm Turns to Brewing
abstract: Arrowood Farms in the Hudson Valley is now serving beers and duck prosciutto made on the farm.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Blake Arrowood, an English teacher in Southeast Asia, decided to become a farmer and cultivated 48 acres in the Hudson Valley, not far from New Paltz, N.Y. He grew hops along with rye, and raised ducks, too, and took on a brewing partner, Jacob Meglio, after the state passed legislation making it easier for farmers to brew beer. The farm now produces nine beers, including one made with organic rye. All are served at the farm, along with duck prosciutto made in-house. The brews are sold and served in the Hudson Valley and also at Malt and Mold’s two Manhattan locations. When the new Rouge Tomate reopens later this summer in Chelsea, a selection of Arrowood’s beers will be the only ones offered on tap: Arrowood Farms, 236 Lower Whitfield Road, Accord, N.Y., 845-253-0389, arrowoodfarms.com.

headline: New Inspiration for Summer Salads
abstract: The cookbook “Leon Happy Salads,” from a London restaurant chain, has clever tips for better-dressed greens.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a cookbook to inspire when the heat is off the charts. Prep time for many of the salads in this colorful volume from Leon, a casual English chain, is five minutes. Bright ideas fill categories like classics, including a Greek salad topped, inventively, with fried feta. Polish herring and potatoes with beets in horseradish cream, and chicken tonnato with artichokes and haricots verts, are meal-worthy. The BKT salad swaps out lettuce for kale, and there are many cool Asian influences in the sprightly dressings. Basic ingredients, salad-making principles (including the architecture involved), an array of crunchy garnishes and dressings are included: “Leon Happy Salads” by Jane Baxter and John Vincent (Conran Octopus, $19.99).

headline: His Assignment: Find the World’s Best Bacon
abstract: Scott Gold is named the bacon critic for Extra Crispy, a breakfast-centric website.
lead_paragraph: Scott Gold, a 39-year-old food writer specializing in meat, beat out around 1,000 applicants for the title of bacon critic for Extra Crispy, Time Inc.’s new website about breakfast, brunch and the foods involved. “This job is tailor-made for me,” he said with gusto. When it comes to bacon, he likes a medium-thick slice and a balance of smoke, fat and salt with an “intensely porcine” quality. He can’t resist the bacon at Peter Luger Steak House in Brooklyn. “Bacon is rarely terrible,” he said. “Who sends back bacon?” At the same time, he acknowledges that spectacular bacon is hard to find. But now he is on the case, given three months to travel around the globe, reporting weekly on his discoveries. In November, at the end of his assignment, he’ll crown one bacon as the best: extracrispy.com.

She’s talking about the fundamentals, too, like packing and planning the day’s activities. “I wanted to have a collection that you can pack in a suitcase to cover all your needs,” she says of her clothing line Deitas. “So it’ll always remain capsule size.” With simple lines, mixable pieces and a muted palette, Deitas cuts down on the plague of morning indecision by offering the ease of a weekend-away-wardrobe at home.

headline: Why Calls for a ‘National Conversation’ Are Futile
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'English Language', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Self-congratulatory discussions inevitably follow moments of discord in the United States. So why aren’t they getting us anywhere?
lead_paragraph: The bad news never seems to cease: death, discrimination, discrimination that culminates in death. Within days in early July, police officers shot and killed Alton Sterling in Baton Rouge, La., then Philando Castile near St. Paul, Minn., both of them black men. On July 7, a sniper murdered five cops during an otherwise peaceful protest in Dallas. Ten days later a different gunman killed three officers in Baton Rouge. This all took place not long after the June massacre at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla., and just before the campaign conventions of the country’s two political parties, during an election year that feels historically nasty. When things get this fractious and this tragic, we inevitably hear calls for a “national conversation.” But during Barack Obama’s presidency, news organizations, politicians and academics have scarcely had to do any calling. Whatever it is we need to talk about is simply added to the mounting agenda.

headline: ‘I Have No Choice but to Keep Looking’

lead_paragraph: Yuko Takamatsu was somewhere in the sea off the coast of Japan. Two and a half years had passed since the tsunami, and no one had found her; but no one was really looking, either, except her husband, Yasuo Takamatsu, who loved her very much. Takamatsu first searched on land, at the bank where she vanished, and along the beaches of Onagawa, and in the forests in the mountains. After two and half years, in September 2013, when he still hadn’t found her, he turned to the sea.

headline: Paradise, the New Muslim Utopia
abstract: These days, one imagines happy tomorrows only after death, not before.

Paradise as a goal for the individual or the group has gradually replaced the dreams of development, stability and wealth promised by postwar decolonization in the so-called Arab world. These days, one imagines happy tomorrows only after death, not before.

Pas seulement l’imaginaire médiéval d’ailleurs, puisque pour beaucoup de musulmans le paradis est aussi au centre du discours politique, du prêche et de l’imaginaire actuels. Le paradis comme but pour l’individu ou le groupe a remplacé peu à peu les rêves de développement, de stabilité et de richesse qu’avaient promis les décolonisations d’après-guerre dans le monde arabe. Désormais on ne parle des lendemains qui chantent que pour après la mort, pas avant.

headline: Can I Put Down My Aging Pooch?
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Dogs', 'Food Stamps', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide', 'Children and Childhood', 'Medicine and Health', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to make a hard decision about an old dog before a stressful trip and weighing politeness against public health when it concerns a contagious child.
lead_paragraph: Our family dog, a 14-year-old terrier, is currently living with my wife and me in Paris. She has made the trans-Atlantic flight three times in the past year (crated in the belly of the plane) when we return home for various family events. The trip is stressful for her (and for me), but she has always rebounded quickly to her normal self, which is a pretty energetic and healthy dog. Recently, however, her health has declined a bit: less energy, hearing loss, brief moments of apparent confusion and an as-yet-unexplained brief seizure. But she is happy and devoted to my wife and me, enjoying meals and daily walks.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: ‘Roc’
abstract: A sometimes-sad sitcom from the 1990s showed what it felt like to be black in America.
lead_paragraph: From the opening notes of its theme song — an a cappella version of “God Bless the Child” — I knew I was going to like “Roc.” That song was one I’d heard my father croon my whole life, its lyrics cutting through the smoke from his cigarette as he grilled hamburgers or reclined on the couch and closed his heavy eyelids. To this day, “God Bless the Child” sounds like home to me. I’ve also come to think it sounds like how I feel as a black person living in America: all at once hopeful, resigned, familial, lonely, beautiful, sad.

So what happens when an operation is subjected to and fails the ultimate test — a clinical trial in which patients are randomly assigned to have it or not?

headline: In Ireland, Chasing the Ghost of the Rebel Roger Casement
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Books and Literature', 'Art', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: A pilgrimage to trace the steps of the Irish-independence and human-rights activist Roger Casement on the centenary of his execution for high treason.
lead_paragraph: It didn’t start with history, and it certainly didn’t start with Roger Casement. After a trip a few years ago, during which I spent a few days each in Belfast, Cork and Dublin, I returned home feeling I’d failed myself, and perhaps failed Ireland, by limiting myself to cities. Next time, I would find a cottage in the countryside, where I would read, and write, and take long head-clearing walks. That was the only mandate I gave myself: the promise of an Irish pastoral in real time.

It has an uncommonly diverse mix of residents and restaurants and a staggering number of pinball machines per capita. Some of its adult-oriented businesses — pornography, poker and marijuana — speak to its rough-and-tumble roots, flourishing there because of the tight restrictions of its more affluent neighbor to the north.

They are the most recent in a long history of abuses. Over the last few years, Mr. Erdogan has harshly repressed the Turkish press and civil society, supported extremist militant groups in Syria, broken off a promising peace process with his country’s Kurdish nationalists, and worked relentlessly to change his country’s Constitution so he can rule as a quasi-dictator.

headline: In ‘Guns on Campus,’ Tamron Hall Examines a Polarizing Issue
abstract: The program looks at the debate over whether college students licensed to carry firearms should be allowed to bring them into classrooms.
lead_paragraph: Investigation Discovery’s lineup is heavy on true crime served sensationally (“Wives With Knives,” “Deadly Affairs”), but the journalist Tamron Hall sometimes brings more serious programming to the channel, as she does on Sunday, Aug. 7, with “Guns on Campus: Tamron Hall Investigates.” The program examines the debate over whether college students licensed to carry firearms should be allowed to bring them into class, but its jumping-off point is an attack 50 years ago at the University of Texas at Austin. Charles Whitman, after killing his wife and his mother at their homes, went to the school’s signature tower and killed 14 more people, three inside and the rest sniper-style from the top of the structure. One of the men who helped end his rampage was an armed civilian, providing Ms. Hall with an avenue to discuss whether armed students might have stopped some of the more recent campus shootings in the United States. It is, of course, a polarizing issue, one that the program explores from both sides.

headline: Twenty One Pilots, Bringing Rock’s Pomp and a Lot More
abstract: The duo will perform two shows at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, Aug. 10 and Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The most important young mainstream rock band of the 2010s isn’t much of a rock band at all. Twenty One Pilots is an amalgam of the sounds made by two decades of the disintegration of arena-size guitar rock. Its platinum 2015 album, “Blurryface,” is adventurous and ambitious; while remaining resolutely pop at its core, it aspires to rock’s pomp without losing sight of how rock’s energy now largely exists in other genres. The result is an album that nails familiar dynamics but with different inputs: nerdy rapping, Sublime-esque reggae-rock, head-bashing dance music, pop-punk, emo and industrial, with more than a dash of Broadway theatricality. The duo will headline a pair of shows at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, Aug. 10, and Thursday. (thegarden.com.)

lead_paragraph: Alice Austen may not be a household name, but scholars of early photography or early feminism may be familiar with her remarkable life. Austen — who was born in 1866 and died in 1952 — is now the subject of a play, “Alice in Black and White,” that explores both her early passion for the then-exotic medium of photography and her long relationship with her lover, Gertrude Tate. Over the course of her life, Austen amassed more than 8,000 images, of which 3,500 survive.

headline: Fresh From Florida, Frederick Ashton’s British Ballet
abstract: In “A Knight of the British Ballet,” at the Joyce Theater, the Sarasota Ballet will celebrate Ashton’s choreography from the 1930s to the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: It’s not uncommon for Americans to retire to Florida, but who knew that the British choreographer Frederick Ashton (1904-88) would end up there, too? The Sarasota Ballet has become a significant repository for his work, which will be showcased in style when the company appears at the Joyce Theater. Beginning on Monday, Aug. 8, “A Knight of the British Ballet” will survey Ashton’s choreography, including “Facade” (1931), a tribute to popular songs and dances of the 1920s, and “Valses nobles et sentimentales” (1947). The program also features “Tweedledum and Tweedledee” (1977), a charming look at those characters; “The Walk to the Paradise Garden,” a homage to “Romeo and Juliet,” set to music by Frederick Delius (1972); and an excerpt from “Jazz Calendar,” called “Friday’s Child,” originally created for Antoinette Sibley and Rudolf Nureyev in 1968. There’s never enough Ashton shown in New York, but mercifully, Florida has come to the rescue. (Through Saturday, Aug. 13; 212-242-0800, joyce.org.)

headline: Robert J. Flaherty, Who Blurred the Line Between Nonfiction and Fiction in Film
abstract: Anthology Film Archives will show his “Nanook of the North” and “Man of Aran,” early documentaries that relied on imagination as much as on fact.
lead_paragraph: Robert J. Flaherty is often called the father of the documentary: The term is said to have originated in a review of his “Moana” (1926). But veracity was not always his primary goal, as evidenced by his silent classic “Nanook of the North” (1922) and the talkie “Man of Aran” (1934), both heading to Anthology Film Archives.

abstract: The transportation and accommodations combo of a camper van rental seemed ideal for a South Florida family vacation on the cheap.
lead_paragraph: At $120 a night during Florida’s notorious spring break, the Art Deco Hotel Shelley had seemed like a bargain. It even included a free airport shuttle to the hotel’s South Beach address, walking distance from where we would pick up our camper van rental the next morning before making a beeline for the Florida Keys. When the shuttle arrived, it was impossible to miss. Wrapped in a wheels-to-roof vinyl ad, the bus was a mobile billboard splashed with the racy, larger-than-life image of a buxom woman — her blond hair thrown back, her face flushed — being caressed by a masked man, red silk around his neck. Next to the door was a slogan: “Quirky + Sexy + Chic No-Tell Hotels.” My husband, infant daughter and I climbed aboard. I had, it seemed, booked my family at what in Mexico is artfully referred to as a “love motel.” Well, I thought, no “Mom of the Year” award for me.

headline: Running for Your Past and Future Self

I notice the texture of the grass on the warm-up field more than I usually do — I also sense my heartbeat more than on a normal day when I don’t notice it at all. Stray frizzy hairs tickle the back of my neck. I try my best to keep the thoughts positive and productive and inspiring. Or at least distracting in a good way. When I step on the starting line, I will need to be razor-focused and entirely present – more so than any other time in my life. But on the warm-up field, it is perfectly fine — in fact, encouraged — to daydream.

headline: How Israel’s Modern-Orthodox Jews Came Out of the Closet

headline: An Under-the-Radar Warhol Alum, at One of Los Angeles’s Coolest Galleries
abstract: The actress, writer, illustrator and artist Mary Woronov’s vibrant, emotive paintings are now on view at the Lodge, a building owned by Ed Ruscha.
lead_paragraph: While studying sculpture at Cornell in 1963, Mary Woronov met Gerard Malanga, the Warhol confidant and chief gatekeeper of Andy Warhol’s Factory. Before long, she was performing as Hanoi Hannah in Warhol’s “Chelsea Girls” and in leather and whips in the Velvet Underground’s dance troupe, The Exploding Plastic Inevitable. A multihyphenate long before it became a buzzword, the cult actress, writer, illustrator and artist would become one of the most indelible figures to emerge from the early years of the Factory. And while some of the passages in her autobiography, “Swimming Underground,” suggest a dystopian world, Woronov sees the Warhol years as the most nurturing and formative of her life. “I have a very dark side, I can’t help it, but to me that period was wine and roses. It was darkness with pinpoints of light,” she says. “My connection with Warhol was sort of like Lancelot’s connection to King Arthur.”

headline: John Waters Tells the Story of His Mustache

lead_paragraph: John Waters doesn’t remember exactly why he first grew his iconic pencil mustache, but he does remember when: 1970. It had only been six years since the Baltimore native graduated high school, and only four since he had been kicked out of NYU during a marijuana bust on campus. But he was already a prolific filmmaker, then working on his fifth film and what he calls his “real” first feature, “Multiple Maniacs” (1970), which will receive a theatrical rerelease at New York’s IFC Center beginning on August 5. “I dressed like a hippie pimp,” he says of his sartorial style during the period when he made the film. “I had long hair and wore ridiculous thrift-shop shirts. The mustache just went along with my sleazy look.”

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Lit’s Dynamic Duo, Will and Jane, Shared Path to Pop Stardom
abstract: The afterlives of William Shakespeare and Jane Austen, and the sometimes over-the-top tokens of fans’ devotion, are the subject of an exhibition in Washington.
lead_paragraph: THERE’S something about pop culture that loves a coupling. Kim and Kanye. Brad and Angelina. Bill and Hillary. Batman and Robin.

headline: Phoenix Rattled as Serial Gunman Leaves 7 Dead and 2 Injured
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police', 'Serial Murders', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: The authorities released a sketch of a man suspected of nine attacks and raised a reward for information to $50,000.
lead_paragraph: On a recent summer evening, a young man and a toddler were in a car stopped in a residential neighborhood in Phoenix when gunfire erupted. The two were not hurt, but investigators later said that it slowly dawned on them that they had a larger crime on their hands: A serial shooter had struck again.

headline: Paul, Weiss Hires 4 Partners to Bolster Antitrust Practice
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: The firm said the move was a response to greater government scrutiny of mergers and acquisitions that might inhibit competition.
lead_paragraph: As regulators continue to clamp down on deals they believe will harm competition, the small group of lawyers who focus on antitrust have become even more in demand.

headline: Lest We Forget, the U.S., Too, Spent Time in the Doping Wilderness
abstract: As we rage about Russia’s state-sponsored doping, we might want to recall those decades when doping was a slice of American pie.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Early in 1987, Kerry Lynch, a bright hope of the American ski team for an Olympic medal, boarded a plane for Germany.

headline: Colombia’s New, Legal Drug Barons Focus on Medical Marijuana
keywords: ['Medical Marijuana', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Colombia revised a 30-year-old drug law and embraced medical marijuana; now private companies are betting that cannabis could be a market leader.
lead_paragraph: RIONEGRO, Colombia — Like many drug barons in Colombia, Federico Cock-Correa wants to sell his product globally. Just 15 miles outside Medellín, Mr. Cock-Correa is looking to replace vast acres of flowers with marijuana plants, with plans to export the harvest.

headline: Review: ‘Olympic Pride, American Prejudice’ Recalls Black Athletes in 1936
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Olympic Games (1936)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Movies', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination']
abstract: This documentary, directed by Deborah Riley Draper, brings racial inequality to the forefront in the Olympics held in Berlin during the Third Reich.
lead_paragraph: The Olympic Games have never been immune from politics, and they certainly weren’t in 1936, when Berlin was the host city and Hitler sought to present the Third Reich in a flattering light. That the United States thwarted him is largely because of the black athletes who receive their due in Deborah Riley Draper’s deft and comprehensive documentary “Olympic Pride, American Prejudice.” As the movie makes clear, racial politics played a major role, both domestically and abroad.

headline: Racism in the Research Lab
abstract: Prejudice in science is suffocating a generation of biomedical researchers.
lead_paragraph: “You are too smart to be Mexican” and “Congratulations! You probably got the award because you are Latino” are two of many remarks we, as scholars and professionals, heard at some of the top academic centers in the country.

headline: Two Artists Built a Spinning House, and Then Moved In
abstract: The structure not only moves with the wind, but also tilts as its inhabitants move across its floor. Here’s what it’s like to live there.
lead_paragraph: For Alex Schweder and Ward Shelley, the term “artist in residence” is often a very literal one: Collaborators since 2007, the pair practice what Schweder describes as “performance architecture,” or the exploration of how inhabiting a space affects us, psychologically. So they build interesting structures, and then move in.

headline: Review: In ‘The Tenth Man,’ Contending With a Father and a Traditional Upbringing
abstract: A charmer with a documentary feel, this film follows a man’s return to Buenos Aires to reconnect with his father in a bustling Jewish neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: “The Tenth Man,” a modest charmer from Argentina, breathes considerable life into the rather trite scenario of a man discovering his religious roots, in part because it seems genuinely curious about the community in which it’s set.

headline: How a Suicide Bomber Made His Way From Syria to Strike in Ansbach, Germany
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Terrorism', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: Mohammad Daleel, 27, wounded 15 people last month, three years after entering Europe illegally through Bulgaria. He received mental health therapy, and his full identity and motives remain unclear.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — To the German authorities, he was Mohammad Daleel, a 27-year-old Syrian traumatized by war who arrived in Europe seeking refuge.

headline: Wet, Wild and Wholesome: ‘Dynamic H2O’ at the Children’s Museum of Manhattan
abstract: Young visitors can get to know the city’s most industrious commuter, one that travels 125 miles from the Catskill Mountains every day to serve New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: The Children’s Museum of Manhattan is inviting young visitors to get to know the city’s most industrious commuter: one that travels 125 miles from the Catskill Mountains every day, ascends countless high-rise floors to serve New Yorkers and leaves only after long hours, thoroughly dirty.

headline: Outstanding Issues: A Yemeni Teenager’s Trip to Estonia, by Way of Guantánamo
abstract: The reporter Charlie Savage wrote about an ex-Guantánamo inmate’s resettlement; the story didn’t end when the article published.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, the reporter Charlie Savage describe the impact of an article he wrote about an ex-Guantánamo detainee — on readers, the subject and the writer.

headline: Review: Dim All the Lights, Again: ‘Will You Dance With Me?’
abstract: Derek Jarman’s test footage shot at an East London disco is being shown as a short feature.
lead_paragraph: In 1984 the director Ron Peck asked a friend and colleague, Derek Jarman, to record test footage for a proposed feature project. About 100 nightclubbers of all stripes, many of them regular patrons of the East London disco where the test was to be shot, were invited, and presumably instructed to act naturally. For that reason, the material that Mr. Jarman captured — recently rediscovered by Mr. Peck and being shown now as a short feature titled “Will You Dance With Me?” — feels like, well, a night out at a tackily appointed, friendly dance club, documented by a regular who’s not intruding on anybody’s fun.

headline: Review: ‘Richard Linklater: Dream Is Destiny’ Lionizes a Maverick Talent
abstract: Louis Black’s film is a cozily chronological ramble through a director’s career highlights and personal reminiscences.
lead_paragraph: If you’re not already in the bag for its subject, then “Richard Linklater: Dream Is Destiny” wants to give your arm an extra twist. Maybe its makers, Louis Black and Karen Bernstein, found neither of the two film profiles from 2014 sufficiently enthusiastic about Mr. Linklater’s resolutely outsider talents; whatever the case, they’ve decided to dive deeper into the kudos and the mind that inspired them.

headline: Bettors Can Seek Gold of Their Own During the Olympics
abstract: International betting firms are offering odds on just about every event at the Summer Games, from archery to yachting.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — When the Olympics open up in earnest on Saturday, you can marvel at the athletic prowess on display, cheer for your favorite country, or just enjoy the spectacle.

headline: Review: The Lobster Scene in ‘Multiple Maniacs’? It Still Startles
abstract: A restoration by the Criterion Collection puts this early John Waters film back on the screen — and in theaters — in all its perverted glory.
lead_paragraph: Ah, those stodgy Nixon-era minders of the national morality. Surely they didn’t need to get as worked up as they did about the early John Waters film “Multiple Maniacs.” Or did they? It does, after all, feature rosary beads as a sex toy. And there’s the rape scene involving a giant lobster.

headline: Martin Frost Explores the Soul of the Clarinet
abstract: Preparing for two intimate Mostly Mozart Festival performances, Mr. Frost talks about silence, vibration, his instrument and Mozart’s early influence.
lead_paragraph: Think of musical virtuosity, and the qualities that most likely come to mind are speed, rhythmic complexity, and extremes of volume and pitch. Long, placid lines sound as if they should be as restful for the player as they are to the listener.

headline: Review: ‘Five Nights in Maine’ Probes the Pain of Loss
abstract: In Maris Curran’s delicate drama, a man whose wife has died goes to visit her mother, and the two slowly examine their grief.
lead_paragraph: Maris Curran had plenty of opportunities to insert a cheesy plot twist into “Five Nights in Maine,” her delicate drama about loss and its aftermath. Yet she stayed true to her intentions, and the result is a believable character study that may not draw crowds but certainly challenges its two lead actors.

headline: Advocacy Groups Allege Abuses on Nauru
abstract: A report by Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International said Australia appeared to be subjecting migrants to abuses at an offshore processing site as "a deliberate policy to deter further asylum seekers from arriving in the country by boat."
lead_paragraph: A report by Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International said Australia appeared to be subjecting migrants to abuses at an offshore processing site as "a deliberate policy to deter further asylum seekers from arriving in the country by boat."

headline: Review: ‘collective:unconscious,’ the Stuff of Dreams Reinterpreted
abstract: In this omnibus work about the individuality of interpretation, five filmmakers transcribed their dreams, which were then directed by others in the group as shorts.
lead_paragraph: A throwback to the Surrealists and exquisite corpse games, the omnibus film “collective:unconscious” began from a simple premise: Five filmmakers transcribed their dreams; each description was then given at random to one of the others to direct as a short. (The film bears no relationship to the theater organization Collective:Unconscious.)

headline: Seven Female Furniture Designers
abstract: The designer Rachel Comey and the artist Leanne Shapton have collaborated on an exhibition featuring Shapton’s abstractions of chairs, lights and tables designed by women.
lead_paragraph: The designer Rachel Comey and the artist Leanne Shapton have collaborated on an exhibition featuring Shapton’s abstractions of chairs, lights and tables designed by women.

headline: Rediscovering Great Female Furniture Designers
abstract: Rachel Comey and Leanne Shapton have collaborated on an exhibition that celebrates the work of the sometimes-overlooked women in the field.
lead_paragraph: One day this spring, Rachel Comey and Leanne Shapton were having lunch when it occurred to them that there was a blind spot in their knowledge of midcentury furniture designers: women. Comey, a fashion designer, was looking for chairs for her new store in L.A. She wanted something designed by a woman — which turned out to be a tall order. On a whim, they went to a few nearby furniture dealers in NoLIta. “We were like, ‘What have you got by women?” Shapton recalls. “And they were like: nothing.”

headline: An Analyst of Gothic Monsters Explores Trump’s Appeal
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A student of Gothic literary monsters assesses Donald Trump’s allure.
lead_paragraph: It’s all the rage in the news media at the moment to dig into Donald J. Trump’s psyche. What mix of narcissism, psychosis and the like could possibly generate such a nonstop series of seeming miscalculations? In The Guardian, thankfully, Dean Burnett, a neuroscientist, standup comic and author of “The Idiot Brain,” has tried to tamp things down, explaining why diagnosing Trump is “likely to do more harm than good.”

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates to Curate French-American Festival
abstract: The author of “Between the World and Me” will bring French and American thinkers together to discuss what national, social and cultural labels mean today.
lead_paragraph: The writer Ta-Nehisi Coates, fresh from a year living in Paris, will be the curator of the third annual Festival Albertine, a free five-day event in New York in November bringing together French and American artists and thinkers.

headline: Arthritis Drug May Have Benefits Against Alzheimer’s
abstract: An inflammation-fighting drug for rheumatoid arthritis may offer protection against Alzheimer’s, a study suggests.
lead_paragraph: A drug used to treat rheumatoid arthritis may have benefits against Alzheimer’s disease, researchers report.

headline: Syrians Burn Tires to Prevent Airstrikes
abstract: Syrian children burned tires in Aleppo, Syria, in hopes of creating a smoke curtain to deter airstrikes.
lead_paragraph: Syrian children burned tires in Aleppo, Syria, in hopes of creating a smoke curtain to deter airstrikes.

headline: Review: A Journey Through Uncharted Waters in ‘Men on Boats’
abstract: There isn’t a man in the 10-member cast of this rollicking history pageant by Jaclyn Backhaus.
lead_paragraph: The Clubbed Thumb Summerworks’ production of “Men on Boats” played through the summer of 2015. Following are excerpts from Ben Brantley’s review, which appeared in The New York Times on June 24, 2015. The full text is here. The play opened on Monday at Playwrights Horizons’ Peter Jay Sharp Theater, 416 West 42nd Street, Manhattan; 212-279-4200, ticketcentral.com.

headline: Review: War Made Terrifyingly Palpable in ‘Citizen Soldier’
abstract: This documentary powerfully uses footage to track a group of American soldiers during a tour of duty in Afghanistan in 2011.
lead_paragraph: The tension in “Citizen Soldier” is enough to make you gnaw through your fingernails. This documentary, which follows a group of American G.I.s in Afghanistan in 2011, uses footage taken during their missions, sometimes via their own helmet cams. The sense of danger is palpable, as is the sense of misery after the most dreadful scenes.

headline: Turkey Issues a Warrant for Fethullah Gulen, Cleric Accused in Coup
abstract: Mr. Gulen, who lives in a self-imposed exile in Pennsylvania, is accused of plotting the July 15 coup attempt that left more than 250 people dead.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey issued an arrest warrant on Thursday for Fethullah Gulen, a Muslim cleric based in the United States, who was accused last month of orchestrating a failed coup against the government of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

headline: Review: In ‘The Brooklyn Banker,’ Troy Garity Shows Promise (With the Mob)
abstract: The latest entry in the gangster genre, this drama concerns a number cruncher who proves more useful for local gangsters than is healthy.
lead_paragraph: It’s 1973 in Brooklyn, and Santo (Troy Garity) is in a tough spot. A young man with a head for numbers, he’s married with two kids and a third on the way, and has a bright future as a vice president for a local bank. He has stayed in the neighborhood and away from the mob ties that entangle his friends and family. At least until his father-in-law, Benny (Paul Sorvino), a lieutenant for the neighborhood don, brings him to the boss, Manny, who needs a favor. “This is good for us,” Benny promises.

headline: Review: ‘War and Turpentine,’ a Grandfather’s Painful Life
abstract: Stefan Hertmans uses his grandfather’s notebooks about World War I to create a harrowing account of war, poverty and despair, stoically endured.
lead_paragraph: Some soldiers return home and are unable or unwilling to talk about their wartime experience. Others speak about little else.

headline: Review: In ‘Front Cover,’ Struggling for Self-Acceptance
abstract: This gay romance, written and directed by Ray Yeung, takes a gentle, thoughtful look at the intersection of ethnicity and sexuality.
lead_paragraph: Though too slight to be memorable, the gay romance “Front Cover” takes a gentle, thoughtful look at the intersection of ethnicity and sexuality.

abstract: The comedians Guy Torry and Dave Attell bring their jokes to Westchester. Mr. Torry will be in West Nyack and Mr. Attell will perform in the Peekskill.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Colored Conventions, a Rallying Point for Black Americans Before the Civil War
abstract: From rousing speeches to resolutions and songs, material related to an activist phenomenon that began in the 1830s is being explored by a team at the University of Delaware.
lead_paragraph: Long before they could take any actual roles in government, black political activists sent thousands of delegates to advocacy events called “colored conventions” that were held starting in the 1830s. The activists drafted legislative petitions demanding better schools and job opportunities and legal protections from bigotry and violence.

headline: Review: Soul of Calypso Elevates the Bollywood-Flavored ‘Bazodee’
abstract: This romance finds an Indian family from London visiting another in Trinidad and Tobago for a party celebrating their children’s engagement.
lead_paragraph: Advertised as a sort of “Bollywood goes Caribbean,” “Bazodee” does indeed borrow cultural conventions from both, and it plays out in the perfect setting, Trinidad and Tobago, which has a heritage rich in Afro-Caribbean and Indian traditions.

headline: Obama Writes Feminist Essay in Glamour
abstract: The president wrote a 1,500-word essay in the magazine, calling for equality and explaining that it was important to his daughters that he be a feminist.
lead_paragraph: In his most extensive remarks about feminism, President Obama wrote an essay for Glamour magazine in which he reflected on American women’s long fight for equality and called on men to fight sexism and create equal relationships.

headline: Hanging Out on Pierre Paulin’s Recliner
abstract: An exhibition at Galerie Perrotin showcases the work of an innovative French designer at home with ’60s Pop and the presidential palace.
lead_paragraph: Something happened to midcentury modernism in the last couple of years: It got boring. Once, the furniture of the Eameses, Eero Saarinen or a clutch of Danes still stood for design innovation; now you can order a tulip chair with one click from Design Within Reach, or head to Overstock.com for a knockoff. Maybe that’s why we’re seeing a revived interest in flashier design from the 1960s and especially the 1970s — the geometric patterns, the shag carpeting, the brass and Lucite. Heck, even “Match Game” is back.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, Aug. 6 Through 14
abstract: Best Coast, featuring the singer and guitarist Bethany Cosentino, will open for the Go Go’s on the band’s farewell tour in Ridgefield.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘Neither Heaven Nor Earth’ Engages the Horrors of War
abstract: In Afghanistan, a captain of French NATO troops and a Taliban commander are forced into an unlikely alliance by a common, invisible enemy in this film.
lead_paragraph: Capt. Antarès Bonassieu, the hero of Clément Cogitore’s debut feature, “Neither Heaven Nor Earth,” seems like a guy we’ve met before, at least in other war movies. Lean and muscular, with a thoughtful countenance under his blond brush cut, he is a seasoned soldier and a natural commander, tough on his men but capable of sensitivity when circumstances require it. (He is played by Jérémie Renier, a graceful chameleon who you may not recognize from Olivier Assayas’s “Summer Hours” or Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne’s “L’Enfant.”

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, Aug. 6 Through 14
abstract: Jill Scott, the songstress who proclaims to live life ‘like it’s golden’ as her lyrics suggest, is to perform at Prudential Hall at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center this month.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Antitrust Lawyer Who Handled Tech Collusion Case to Join Private Firm
abstract: James J. Tierney oversaw a complaint accusing Silicon Valley companies of colluding not to recruit each others’ employees.
lead_paragraph: James J. Tierney, the government antitrust lawyer who oversaw the complaint accusing six major Silicon Valley companies of colluding not to recruit competitors’ employees, is leaving the federal job to join the law firm Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe.

headline: Review: Fanciful Classic ‘The Little Prince’ Is Turned Into Modernist Fable
abstract: A gray corporate world rendered in computer graphics enfolds the stop-motion universe of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry’s tender tale.
lead_paragraph: The masterstroke of “The Little Prince,” Mark Osborne’s reimagining of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry’s 1943 children’s classic, is its side-by-side use of two styles of animation. Today’s cold, corporate world, in which gray-faced, hunched-over adults grimly slog through life, is depicted in severe, rectilinear computer-generated animation. The magical universe of Saint-Exupéry’s wistful, poetic novella is rendered in stop-motion animation, with pastel shades that evoke his original watercolor illustrations.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Animal Rights Protesters: Trumps ‘Have Killed a Lot of Animals’
abstract: Secret Service agents briefly surrounded the Democratic nominee as she was interrupted at a campaign event in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Hillary Clinton came here on Thursday to talk jobs, debt-free college, renewable energy and other planks of the Democratic platform.

headline: Review: In Final Season of ‘Inspector Lewis,’ Solving Mysteries While Navigating a New Boss
abstract: In the last episodes, running on PBS, a new chief superintendent wants to cut costs, and Inspector Lewis is always in the position of proving himself.
lead_paragraph: When “Inspector Morse” ended — 15 years ago! — the Oxford detective Endeavour Morse keeled over in the middle of campus, his dramatic collapse and subsequent death the appropriate capstone for a series about a self-centered snob. When its spinoff “Inspector Lewis” ends in a few weeks, no one of importance will die. Call that a spoiler, but if you’ve watched Morse’s onetime sergeant, Robbie Lewis, over his nearly 30 years on television, you know that he’d find being killed off far too immodest, too attention-grabbing a fate.

lead_paragraph: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

headline: How Sunflowers Follow the Sun, Day After Day
abstract: New research has revealed that the plant’s internal clock and ability to detect light work together to allow the flower to face east as the sun rises and bend to the west.
lead_paragraph: At dawn, whole fields of sunflowers stand at attention, all facing east, and begin their romance with the rising sun. As that special star appears to move across the sky, young flowers follow its light, looking up, then over and westward, catching one final glance as the sun disappears over the horizon.

headline: Review: In ‘Little Men,’ Boys Develop a Bond That Is Threatened by Money
abstract: In an adventure story edged with unspoken risks, the young actors take the kind of chances that their more careful elders have been trained to avoid.
lead_paragraph: There is hardly a shortage of buddy movies about mismatched men bonding under duress, but films that chart the emotional weather of everyday male friendship are rare. Literature has more to offer, at least as far as boys are concerned. Tom Sawyer and Huckleberry Finn have a rich and renewable legacy. And it may be that association that imparts a novelistic vibe to Ira Sachs’s “Little Men,” beyond the Louisa May Alcott echo in the title. It’s a subtle movie, alert to the almost imperceptible currents of feeling that pass between its title characters.

headline: Bar Association Considers Striking ‘Honeys’ From the Courtroom
abstract: An effort to bar sexist or discriminatory comments by lawyers addressing each other has been criticized for inhibiting the ability to speak freely.
lead_paragraph: When Lori Rifkin asked the opposing lawyer to stop interrupting her while she questioned a potential witness, he replied: “Don’t raise your voice at me. It’s not becoming of a woman.”

headline: Pilot of Vanished Malaysian Flight Had Deviant Route on His Simulator, Minister Says
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Pilots', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The Malaysian government acknowledged for the first time that the pilot of Flight 370, which is believed to have crashed in the southern Indian Ocean in 2014, had practiced such a route.
lead_paragraph: The pilot of the Malaysia Airlines jetliner that mysteriously vanished more than two years ago had used his personal flight simulator to practice a path over the remote southern Indian Ocean, where the aircraft is believed to have crashed, the country’s transport minister said on Thursday.

headline: Olympic Officials Set Russia’s Roster; More Than 100 Are Barred for Doping
abstract: But legal challenges remain likely, creating further confusion on the eve of the Rio Games.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Olympic officials announced on Thursday night that 271 Russian athletes had been approved to compete in the Rio Games — 118 fewer than the country had hoped to enter.

headline: Another Airbag Maker Is Under Scrutiny After Fatal Rupture
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: A death in Canada was the first known fatality linked to a rupture in an airbag from a supplier other than Takata.
lead_paragraph: Airbags made by a Tennessee supplier came under heightened scrutiny on Thursday after a rupture in one of its bags was linked to the death of a driver in Canada last month.

headline: Arrested Protester of Baton Rouge Police Shooting Files Suit
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The suit by DeRay Mckesson says that the police “employed unconstitutional tactics to disturb, disrupt, infringe upon and criminalize” the rights of assembly and free speech.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — DeRay Mckesson is a prominent voice of the Black Lives Matter movement who was arrested in July while protesting the fatal police shooting of a Baton Rouge man selling CDs outside a convenience store. On Thursday, he filed a proposed class-action lawsuit against the city of Baton Rouge and several law enforcement agencies.

headline: A Peace Is Broken
keywords: ['Police', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Cases like Karina Vetrano’s, the jogger who was found strangled near her home in Howard Beach, Queens, tend to jolt us into more cautious habits temporarily.
lead_paragraph: In an ordinary summer, a season in which we were not preoccupied by recurring instances of terrorism, police violence and a raucously operatic presidential election threatening the fate of the republic, an incident of the kind that took place in the marshlands surrounding Jamaica Bay, in Queens, on an atypically cool evening might have easily ignited collective tensions.

headline: Fred Tomlinson, Singer Who Led a ‘Monty Python’ Troupe, Dies at 88
abstract: The arranger and his spoofing vocalists sang about Spam, lumberjacks and more for the comedy show.
lead_paragraph: Fred Tomlinson, a singer and arranger who led a troupe of vocalists on “Monty Python’s Flying Circus” and other British television shows, died on July 17. He was 88.

headline: Robert Rosencrans, Who Helped Propel C-Span, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Rosencrans saw the broad potential of cable television when fewer than one in five homes was wired for it.
lead_paragraph: Robert Rosencrans, a daring cable television industry pioneer who was instrumental in creating C-Span, the unfiltered public affairs network that faithfully covers government proceedings and civic events, died on Wednesday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 89.

headline: Looking Back (and Learning From) ‘The Mary Tyler Moore Show’
abstract: Though other shows featured independent women, Ms. Moore’s series really stuck with viewers, during its run, from 1970 to 1977, and after.
lead_paragraph: If Hillary Rodham had gone home and flipped on the TV after she delivered her Wellesley commencement address in the spring of 1969, how might she have seen the changing roles of American women reflected in popular entertainment? She could have watched Mary Tyler Moore — but it would have been in reruns of “The Dick Van Dyke Show,” where Rose Marie was the wisecracking career woman and Ms. Moore still the TV housewife, albeit the first to swap her aproned skirt for capri pants. It was not until a year after Mrs. Clinton’s classmates tossed their mortarboards that Mary Richards first tossed her tam in “The Mary Tyler Moore Show.”

headline: $400 Million to Iran Was Not a Ransom, Obama Says
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Prisoners', 'Kidnapping and Hostages']
abstract: The president called the uproar over the payment, which was made public at the time as part of a landmark nuclear pact, “the manufacturing of outrage.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Thursday flatly denied that a $400 million pallet of cash delivered to the Iranian government in January, on the same day that four American citizens who had been detained by Iran were released, was a ransom payment, calling the latest uproar over the landmark nuclear pact with Tehran “the manufacturing of outrage.”

But they told me that I didn’t have the papers needed to do that job in their country, so I went to work in a shawarma restaurant instead. I started out cleaning dishes and washing the place. It was not easy. The money was small, and four of us lived in two rooms. I had to go every two months to renew my asylum papers. For four years, I could never be permanent. Waiting in those queues, I could think only: I have to leave here. I cannot stay.

lead_paragraph: On Oct. 9, 1982, the songwriter and producer Patrick Cowley observed the release event for his third solo album, “Mind Warp,” from the mezzanine of the glamorous Galleria event space at the San Francisco Design Center. Mr. Cowley, the disco innovator who spawned hi-NRG — an up-tempo, mechanized strain of dance music calibrated for the peak of the party — wore black patent-leather pants and a matching jacket. The sickly-sweet smell of the inhalant club drug known as poppers wafted up from the dance floor, where gay men dressed in jeans and white T-shirts churned to the album’s breathless pulse. But the revelry belied the grim content of “Mind Warp,” a meditation on the body besieged that Mr. Cowley created while withering from the effects of a mysterious affliction.

A few minutes earlier, I had taken one look at the elevator in the lobby and determined: No way. If there was an alternate route up, I would find it. My husband shot a knowing look my way and piled into the metal box with too many other guests — an image, even as I write this, that makes me uneasy — riding what The New York Times in 1891 called the “vertical railway.”

headline: Inside the List
abstract: J. D. Vance, whose memoir “Hillbilly Elegy” is No.9 on the hardcover nonfiction list, says, “It’s amazing how much just knowing other people changes the way you think and talk about them.”
lead_paragraph: Moving On Up: Any way you look at it, J. D. Vance is a member of the elite — a Yale Law graduate and former biotech executive who is now, in his early 30s, a principal at a San Francisco investment firm. But it wasn’t always thus. In the memoir “Hillbilly Elegy,” new at No. 9 on the hardcover nonfiction list, Vance details his childhood in a poor Ohio town among a chaotic extended family with a mother who turned to drugs and a string of unstable relationships. Along the way, he takes a cleareyed look at some vexing and intractable problems facing the white underclass, which in my reading makes his book a kind of Appalachian version of Ta-­Nehisi Coates’s ­“Between the World and Me” (at No. 6 after 55 weeks on the list) and a more intimate companion volume to Nancy Isenberg’s cultural study “White Trash” (at No. 10 after six weeks).

headline: The Most Stunning New Store in Paris’s Haute Jewelry Mecca
abstract: With the help of Rem Koolhaas, the designer Gaia Repossi‘s new flagship boutique is an architectural feat — not unlike her own designs.
lead_paragraph: Micro architectures. That is how Gaia Repossi describes the fine jewelry she designs. Not as multi-carat baubles. Or haute fantasias — the provenance of most high-end jewelers. But strict architectural works conceived as human adornment. A series of segmented rings joined by a simple line across the phalanx references the Brutalist lines of Le Corbusier. Delicately looping squiggles suggest, simultaneously, the world of Calder and the spectral images of radio waves.

headline: The Ever-So-Stylish Newspaper Salesman

lead_paragraph: Steeve Mackaya arrives each morning before rush hour with three stacks of newspapers, two milk crates and, rain or shine, a different boldly colored suit. I asked him what he wanted, if he wanted money. He said he wanted nothing. He just wanted to say his piece.”

headline: Snowy Egrets, Once Fashion Victims, Always Elegant Predators
abstract: The birds’ population plummeted in the late 1880s as a result of plume-hunting, an inspiration for the Migratory Bird Treaty Act. They are again common in summer.
lead_paragraph: There is nothing as white as a snowy egret, and few things are as graceful. Watching one hunt in the shallow waters of Hamilton Beach, Queens, one early morning, I was held rapt for almost an hour by the bird’s search for prey. Its image reflected perfectly in the dark mirror of the Hawtree Creek, it was as if two birds hunted. The scene was like a masterful Japanese print; minimal, carefully rendered and capturing an ancient truth. I pitied the school of killifish the bird had targeted.

headline: How Daymond John, a ‘Shark Tank’ Investor, Spends His Sundays
abstract: For Mr. John, Sundays are about escaping Manhattan and relaxing at his cabin in Dutchess County, where he fishes, grills, flips tires and throws knives.
lead_paragraph: Daymond John, an investor on the ABC reality series “Shark Tank,” travels roughly 280 days a year. When he is in New York, chances are he is in Midtown. From the Empire State Building, Mr. John, 47, runs Fubu, an apparel company he founded with three friends in Queens nearly a quarter-century ago. After work, he simply crosses the street to get home, where he lives with his partner, Heather Taras, and their 5-month-old daughter, Minka, in a high-rise. It is a convenient setup for work, but when it is time to play he prefers woodpeckers and grass to concrete and pigeons. On weekends, he sometimes skips town and drives north to his cabin in Dutchess County, which sits on several hundred acres.

abstract: There has been a surge of interest in travel to Britain following its vote to leave the European Union — and low prices may be a reason.
lead_paragraph: It has not been even two months since Britain voted to leave the European Union, and already, the travel industry is seeing the effects of the decision. While it’s too soon to determine how travel to Britain will be affected in the long term, for the time being, with the exchange rate of the pound at a more than 30-year low  compared with the dollar, the region seems to be a more appealing destination for travelers from the United States.

headline: Can G.O.P. Tell Donald Trump, ‘You’re Fired’? Probably Not

abstract: Republican rules and a lack of precedent and time make it almost impossible for the party to dump Donald Trump and nominate someone else.
lead_paragraph: We are in the midst of yet another of Donald J. Trump’s self-inflicted spirals of terrible news. And with prominent Republicans saying they will back Hillary Clinton and others announcing this week that they won’t endorse Mr. Trump, there has been yet another round of speculation about how the party could get rid of him.

headline: 2 Muslim American Women Ordered Off American Airlines Flight
abstract: Niala Khalil said that she and a friend were told to leave the plane this week after it was on the tarmac for hours in Miami.
lead_paragraph: Two Muslim American women were ordered off an American Airlines plane in Miami this week after a flight attendant said that overhearing them talking with other passengers about the lack of food and water on the flight made him uncomfortable, one of the women said.

lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: Where a Queens Jogger Died, Residents Warn: Don’t Go There Alone
abstract: Known as the Weeds, the reed-choked interior of Spring Creek Park in the Howard Beach neighborhood, where the body of Karina Vetrano was found, has long been a part of local lore.
lead_paragraph: Local residents call it the Weeds. Or the Baja, because it is a dirt-filled peninsula. It is the reed-choked interior of Spring Creek Park in Howard Beach, Queens, where Karina Vetrano, 30, went alone for an evening jog on Tuesday and never came out.

headline: Why Frank Ocean and Other Big Names Prefer the Sudden Digital Drop
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: Digital music has eaten into the record industry’s profits from album sales, but it also gives artists something appealing: more creative control.
lead_paragraph: As the music world eagerly awaits the inscrutable R&B singer Frank Ocean’s sophomore album, “Boys Don’t Cry” — which could arrive digitally at any moment via Apple Music — it’s worth considering how we got to this point of nail-chewing uncertainty about big records’ release dates.

headline: NBC’s Rio Plans: A Focus on Prime Time and a Flood of Streaming
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2016)', 'Television Sets and Media Devices', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: NBCUniversal’s broadcast strategy for the Rio Games will show a media giant more than ever straddling two approaches to attract viewers to is prized sports property.
lead_paragraph: NBCUniversal’s broadcast of the Summer Olympics from Rio de Janeiro is showing a media giant more than ever straddling two approaches — old-style television and live video streaming — to attract viewers to its prized sports property.

headline: Doping Sample Bottles, No Longer Seen as Tamper-Proof, Endure
abstract: Thousands of glass bottles, central to accounts of rampant cheating at the last Olympics, are set to be used at the Rio Games.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Most of the key figures involved in Russia’s elaborate doping scheme at the 2014 Sochi Olympics will not participate in the Rio Games. The lab director who blew the whistle is living in the United States, and implicated government officials were told not to attend.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: The Boy With Nighttime Fevers Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the mysterious case of the little boy from Minnesota with fevers and night sweats.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday we asked Well readers to take on the case of a 7-year-old boy who’d been having fevers and drenching sweats nightly for over a month. More than 300 of you wrote in, and although 20 of you came up with the right diagnosis, only three of you figured out both the diagnosis and the test needed to confirm it.

headline: Conversations: Why Many Turks Blame the United States for the Coup
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Extradition', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Members of the Turkish parliament explain how the July 15 coup attempt is seen in Turkey.
lead_paragraph: Turkey is making a full-court press to get the United States to extradite Fethullah Gulen, a Muslim cleric who has lived in exile in Pennsylvania for nearly 20 years and is accused by the government of masterminding the July 15 aborted coup. As part of that effort, a delegation of Turkish parliament members held talks with American officials in Washington, D.C., this week. Three of them – Taha Ozhan, chairman of the foreign affairs committee, delegation leader and a member of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s AK Party; Oguz Kaan Salici of the main opposition Republican People’s Party; and Kamil Aydin, of the Nationalist Movement Party, another opposition party — also met The New York Times Editorial Board, which recently published an editorial criticizing Turkey for accusing the United States of complicity in the insurrection and fueling a new wave of anti-Americanism.

headline: Taking ‘Fun Home’ to Orlando, for a Catharsis Onstage and Off
abstract: The actor Michael Cerveris describes the resonance of a special performance the cast gave in Florida to honor the victims of the Pulse nightclub massacre.
lead_paragraph: Six weeks after the mass shootings at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla., the cast of “Fun Home” left Broadway to put on a special benefit performance there. “Fun Home,” which won the Tony Award for best musical last year, is a poignant exploration of family relationships, sexuality and suicide adapted from a graphic memoir by the cartoonist Alison Bechdel, who is represented in the show by three actresses playing her at different stages of her life.

headline: How ‘The Little Prince’ Came to Animated Life
abstract: A combination of computer-generated animation, paper cutouts and stop-motion effects gave dimension to the story.
lead_paragraph: When the director Mark Osborne was asked to adapt Antoine de Saint-Exupéry’s popular 1943 novella “The Little Prince” into a computer-generated animation film, he was skeptical about the chances of success.

headline: How Dell Raised $67 Billion for the Biggest Tech Deal Ever
abstract: It took months of complicated financial maneuvering at a tumultuous time in the markets to raise money for the industry’s largest takeover ever.
lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — When Dell first announced its $67 billion deal to buy the fellow technology giant EMC last year, the transaction faced no small amount of skepticism — in large part because it was simply so expensive.

headline: U.S. Could Exceed Goal of Accepting 10,000 Syrian Refugees
abstract: After a slow start and amid fierce political controversy, the Obama administration said on Friday that 8,000 Syrian refugees had arrived since October.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — When Madiha Algothany and her family, Syrian refugees who had fled to Jordan, arrived in the United States in June, they braced for rejection from a new culture and country they feared did not want them.

lead_paragraph: Watching slow-motion footage of an event can certainly improve our judgment of what happened. But can it also impair judgment?

headline: 13 Killed in Separatist Attack in Northeastern India
abstract: It was the first major assault in nearly two years in a restive part of the state of Assam, where an ethnic group has been clamoring for autonomy.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Militant separatists armed with grenades and assault rifles attacked a crowded market in the northeast state of Assam on Friday, killing at least 13 people and wounding 16, police officials said. It was the first major assault in the restive region in nearly two years.

headline: Sandbaths, a Huge Butterfly Net and More Choreographed Whimsy
abstract: Tatiana Baganova’s Provincial Dances Theater and the Rosie Herrera Dance Theater aimed for surreal effects in performances at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: The American Dance Festival, six weeks of performances and classes in Durham, N.C., wrapped up in July. But this summer, the festival has had a New York coda of sorts, presenting two artists from its 82nd season at the Joyce Theater: Tatiana Baganova and her company Provincial Dances Theater, from Yekaterinburg, Russia, and the Cuban-American choreographer Rosie Herrera, whose troupe is based in Miami.

headline: Hillary’s New Go-To Gesture: Hand to the Heart
abstract: Did it start with Justin Trudeau? Angelina Jolie? Now Mrs. Clinton and Michelle Obama are putting their hands on their hearts, too.
lead_paragraph: When Hillary Clinton told her audience at a rally in Las Vegas on Thursday “Here’s what I believe,” she punctuated those words with not just a vocal flourish but a physical one. Up went her hand, placed over her heart.

headline: Jesse Eisenberg on the Surprising Success of ‘The Spoils’ in London
abstract: Mr. Eisenberg and Scott Elliott, the show’s director, discussed the play and the differences between American and British audiences.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Importing Jesse Eisenberg’s “The Spoils” to this city was not exactly a no-brainer. Written by and starring Mr. Eisenberg, this lacerating comedy of humiliation — about a whiny, rich, hyper-articulate and terminally narcissistic young New Yorker who impulsively sabotages his own life and that of his Nepalese roommate — appeared destined to be lost in translation.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a recent Saturday, Ian Rawes, a part-time deliveryman, spent several hours walking around London with two microphones strapped to his head. He went into a vegetable market and got so caught up recording the sound of birds in its rafters that he almost got hit by a cabbage-laden forklift hurtling toward him.

headline: As Job Growth Goes, So Goes the Election?
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Strong job gains in July are good news for Democrats.
lead_paragraph: The jobs report for July, showing that employers added 255,000 positions last month, is good news in several ways. It shows that slow economic growth in the second quarter did not prevent the economy from adding jobs in July.

headline: 8 Olympians Who’ve Got Social Media Game
abstract: Athletes who can tweet as well as they compete.
lead_paragraph: Over 11,000 athletes have spent much of their lives preparing for the Rio 2016 Olympics, which begin with tonight’s opening ceremony. Somehow, between training, competing, eating and sleeping, many of them have managed to build social media presences that reflect their sportsmanship and their personalities. Below are a few to watch as the games kick off.

headline: Moment in Convention Glare Shakes Up Khans’ American Life
abstract: How Khizr and Ghazala Khan, parents of a soldier killed in Iraq, came to challenge Donald J. Trump and reshape a presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Six minutes and one second. That was all it took for the 66 years of Khizr Khan’s life to become an American moment.

headline: Ahmed H. Zewail, Nobel-Prize-Winning Chemist, Dies at 70
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Egyptian-Americans', 'Nobel Prizes', 'Chemistry', 'Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)']
abstract: Dr. Zewail, a naturalized American citizen, was the first Arab to win a Nobel in any of the sciences, and he championed science in Egypt and the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Ahmed H. Zewail, an Egyptian-American who won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1999 for developing a revolutionary technique to observe the dance of molecules as they break apart and come together in chemical reactions, died on Tuesday. He was 70.

headline: Black Activists Don’t Ignore Crime
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The work of grass-roots organizations to make streets safer doesn’t get news media attention.
lead_paragraph: IT has become a standard conservative talking point: Black activists focus on police brutality but ignore violent crime in black neighborhoods. Last month Rudy Giuliani said on Fox News: “If they meant ‘Black Lives Matter,’ they would be doing something about the way in which the vast majority of blacks are killed in America, which is by other blacks.”

headline: The Olympic Events to Watch: Saturday
abstract: A guide to the day’s major competitions.
lead_paragraph: Women’s Soccer: The United States figures to get an early challenge from France in its second preliminary game. The French were in line to face the Americans in the semifinals of last year’s World Cup with six minutes to go in France’s match with Germany. France had a 1-0 lead, but a controversial hand-ball call enabled Germany to tie the score on a penalty kick. Germany then went on to win in a shootout, 5-4, delaying France’s coming-out party.

headline: Starlin Castro Hits His First Grand Slam as the Yankees Top the Indians
abstract: Mark Teixeira had two hits and scored twice on Friday night. Andrew Miller did not play in his return to New York after being traded last Sunday.
lead_paragraph: During parts of two seasons with the Yankees, reliever Andrew Miller kept with tradition and stayed perpetually clean-shaven. When he returned to the Bronx on Friday as a member of the Cleveland Indians, Miller sported a noticeable swath of facial hair, looking more relaxed.

headline: Donald Trump Endorses Paul Ryan and John McCain in Bid for G.O.P. Unity
abstract: Mr. Trump, who had caused a rift by withholding support for Mr. Ryan, also called for the re-election of Senator Kelly Ayotte as he sought to move past a tumultuous week.
lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — Donald J. Trump belatedly endorsed the re-elections of Speaker Paul D. Ryan and Senators John McCain and Kelly Ayotte on Friday, moving to heal a deepening rift within the Republican Party touched off by Mr. Trump’s feud with the parents of a slain American soldier.

headline: Why We Ask to See Candidates’ Tax Returns
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Income Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Evasion', 'Watergate Affair']
abstract: It’s because of President Nixon, who did turn out to be a “crook.”
lead_paragraph: Boston — Lost in the debate over Donald J. Trump’s refusal to release his tax returns is the story of where the custom of disclosure comes from — and why it can be so valuable as a measure of character. It’s a tale of presidential tax shenanigans, political scandal and one of the most famous quotations in American history: Richard M. Nixon’s “I am not a crook.”

headline: Orlando Gunman Was Shot at Least 8 Times, Autopsy Finds
abstract: Omar Mateen, whose June 12 shooting at an Orlando nightclub left 49 dead, was shot at least eight times by responding police officers.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Florida said Friday that Omar Mateen, whose June 12 rampage  at an Orlando nightclub left 49 other people dead, was shot at least eight times by police officers who responded to the deadly mass shooting.

headline: Stuck in Platitudes on Migration Crisis
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Editorials']
abstract: Addressing the global exodus of refugees and migrants will require concrete, binding commitments.
lead_paragraph: Diplomats at the United Nations spent several months trying to come up with a comprehensive plan to address today’s flow of refugees and migrants, the largest since World War II. So far they have failed, as became clear last month when they released a platitude-laden blueprint for a discussion of the crisis by world leaders who will convene in New York in September.

headline: The ‘Stranger Things’ School of Parenting
abstract: Remembering the days when kids were free to roam.
lead_paragraph: When the middle-schoolers on the Netflix show “Stranger Things” ride their bikes through the woods around their small town, it’s a clear nod to “E.T.” But those scenes are also reminders of something else: unsupervised childhood.

headline: A Gilded Olympics Begin With the Opening Ceremony in Gritty Rio

lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — If there was a nation in need of an uplifting spectacle at this moment, even in the form of a public relations exercise, it was Brazil.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, August 6, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “The Khans didn’t become bitter when they lost their son or become angry with the military. The exact opposite. They showed tremendous pride in us.”

headline: New York State Test Scores Inspire Conflicting Interpretations
abstract: Politicians, educators and advocates of every stripe have offered clashing views on the results of this year’s standardized exams.
lead_paragraph: When the New York State Education Department announced scores last week from this year’s standardized tests, it led with the good news — nearly 38 percent of students statewide were proficient in English and about 39 percent were proficient in math, up from the previous year’s results. But it also warned that the scores could not be compared with previous results “apples to apples,” because of changes in the way the tests were written and given.

headline: Broken Promises to Homeless Vets
abstract: The government always seems to be making, neglecting, forgetting and rediscovering its covenant with veterans.
lead_paragraph: Speaking to disabled veterans on Monday in Atlanta, President Obama discussed his administration’s efforts to end “the tragedy, the travesty” of veteran homelessness. He proudly declared the glass half full. “We have now reduced the number of homeless veterans by 47 percent,” he said. The number of homeless veterans is now under 40,000.

headline: Olympic Swimmer Elizabeth Beisel Has Music Dripping From Her Fingertips
abstract: Beisel, who won two medals at the 2012 Games, was a prodigy on the piano and violin and still has aspirations when her Olympic career reaches its conclusion.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — This city pulses with an energy that compels a bus driver to fill the silence with song as he sits idly in traffic. It pulses with a rhythm that prompts a woman on a custodial crew in Olympic Park to thrum on a garbage can lid to music only she can hear as an elevator sweeps her off the ground floor. Like her Brazilian hosts, the United States Olympian Elizabeth Beisel has the music in her, too.

headline: Thousands of Roaming Dogs Are Cited as Problem in Poor Areas of Dallas
abstract: A mauling death brought new attention to the issue of unattended dogs, with a study finding that dog bites in the city had increased 15 percent a year since 2013.
lead_paragraph: As consultants drove through the streets of southern Dallas this summer to document the city’s increasing population of loose dogs, they found some residents walking with sticks in hand, in case they had to fend one off.

headline: Jets’ Practice Turns Testy as Two Stars Get Into a Skirmish
abstract: Receiver Brandon Marshall and cornerback Darrelle Revis taunted, tested and tormented each other as the rest of the team was reduced to bystanders.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets have practiced eight times this training camp, which means that eight times — in the humidity of their field house inside, or the scorching temperatures outside — they have competed against one another for balls, for attention, for roster spots. Five of those practices, including Friday’s, were conducted in pads.

headline: Even on NBC, Rio’s Colors Can’t Be Airbrushed Out
abstract: The opening ceremony, when it finally arrived on tape delay, was firmly in the approved, Cirque du Soleil style. But NBC couldn’t obscure the parts that took on larger concerns.
lead_paragraph: Brazil’s signature contribution to world culture is its popular music, and the characteristic mood of that music is the melancholy yearning called saudade. That is not the mood NBC wants you in while you’re watching its coverage of the 2016 Rio Olympics, however.

abstract: A glorious blur of international style — and selfie sticks — prevailed at the Rio opening ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Sulu, gho, kera, kalpak, dishdasha and dashiki sound more like crossword puzzlers than words in common parlance. Yet they are the names of elements of costumes that, for centuries, denoted national identity and are now taken out of cultural mothballs for the Olympics.
