headline: Election Shows Many South Africans Losing Faith in ‘Pompous’ A.N.C.
abstract: Black, middle-class voters appeared more concerned with mundane matters like good governance and taxes than with the party’s heroic liberation past.
lead_paragraph: CHANTELLE, South Africa — A week before South Africa’s local elections on Wednesday, the Zithas held a family meeting inside their entertainment room to decide how to vote. Loyal backers of the African National Congress in every election since the end of apartheid, the family decided it was time for a change.

headline: An All-Star Dance Gala Takes Risks and Soars
abstract: At the Vail International Dance Festival, the artistic director Damian Woetzel revived rare works and brought fresh faces to classical showpieces.
lead_paragraph: VAIL, Colo. — Often the greatest excitement at an all-star dance gala comes from reading the list of illustrious participants. The programs, too commonly a numbing pileup of tired showpieces and frustrating excerpts, disappoint. But the International Evenings of Dance at the Vail International Dance Festival here on Friday and Saturday night were not that kind of gala.

headline: Rebel Offensive in Syria Challenges Government Siege of Aleppo
abstract: A coalition including the jihadist group formerly known as the Nusra Front seized military facilities and tentatively opened a road into rebel-held districts.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Rebel forces and their jihadist allies challenged the Syrian government’s siege of opposition-held districts of Aleppo over the weekend, seizing military facilities in the city’s southwest and tentatively opening a road to the besieged area.

headline: ‘Playing Dead,’ a Disappearing Act for the Fraudulent-Minded
abstract: Drowning in debt and tempted to line up a handy corpse? Elizabeth Greenwood’s book explores death fraud and offers a rough primer on erasing yourself.
lead_paragraph: “There is but one truly serious philosophical problem,” Camus wrote, “and that is suicide. Judging whether life is or is not worth living amounts to answering the fundamental question of philosophy.” Camus was silent, as far as I know, on the subject of “pseudocide,” the term for faking one’s own death.

headline: Review: For ‘Agatha Raisin,’ Playing Detective in an English Village
abstract: Ashley Jensen stars as an aggressive publicist turned crime solver in a new British series on Acorn.
lead_paragraph: Not all detectives have to be brooding, whiskey-swilling clouds of gloom. Not all of them even have to be real detectives. The delightful Agatha Raisin is the latest proof.

headline: Prudential Macro Policy
abstract: Still time to borrow and spend.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, it was easy to say what U.S. monetary and fiscal policy should be doing. The economy was still obviously depressed, so the indicated demand policy was pedal to the metal all the way – no need to worry about inflation, no reason to believe that deficit spending would cause any crowding out (in fact it would almost surely crowd in private investment, because such investment depends on demand.)

headline: A Cri de Coeur From Jazz Musicians in a Black Lives Matter Age
abstract: On Friday, the jazz trumpeter Terence Blanchard performed an elegy for Eric Garner in Staten Island. Other artists have been equally expressive in the age of Black Lives Matter.
lead_paragraph: The emotional climax of Terence Blanchard’s SummerStage concert on Friday night, at Clove Lakes Park on Staten Island, arrived precisely one hour in, like a timed detonation. It was the title track of his most recent album, “Breathless” — an elegy for Eric Garner, who died at the hands of police officers on Staten Island just over two years ago. Mr. Blanchard, in his trumpet solo over the plaintive theme, struck a careful tonal balance, sounding haunted but unflinching.

headline: At Seattle Art Fair, the Interaction Between Technology and Modern Life
abstract: Now in its second year, the fair founded by the Microsoft billionaire Paul Allen featured artists such as Dawn Kasper, Adam McEwen and Wynne Greenwood.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Physicists, picking up where Einstein left off, say the titanic impact of two black holes colliding can make a sound detectable through gravitational waves that wash across space and time. Dawn Kasper, in trying to create her version of that sound as a project for the Seattle Art Fair, said she thought it might be a little like the fading echoes of a great Seattle rock show, in the resonant hum of a crashing cymbal.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Aug. 8
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Review: In ‘Alice in Black and White,’ a Pioneering Photojournalist
abstract: This biographical play at 59E59 Theaters profiles Alice Austen, a 19th- and 20th-century photographer who chronicled city life and defied conventions of her day.
lead_paragraph: Alice Austen loved her Staten Island estate, Clear Comfort. “If somebody made me go away, it would be like a chunk torn out of my body,” she says early in the new biographical play “Alice in Black and White.”

headline: Long View
abstract: Zhouqin Burnikel and Don Gagliardo return with huge ideas.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — For some solvers, themes get in the way of a good free-form crossword puzzle, one where the really cool entries stretch across and down the grid with abandon. Admittedly, themes put constraints on constructors because it takes a lot of skill to place a set of entries in a symmetrical grid without sacrificing other things. For my money, though, themes are bonus content that not only present a challenge to the puzzle maker, but are also a leg up to the crossword solver.

headline: Alex Rodriguez’s Future Resolved, Yankees Settle In and Beat Indians
abstract: The announcement of Rodriguez’s retirement closed a chapter in Yankees history as the team shifts its focus to a younger, developing roster.
lead_paragraph: Luis Severino sat in the Yankees’ clubhouse Sunday morning, inquisitively viewing several televisions that were broadcasting speculation about Alex Rodriguez’s future. Late Saturday night, the Yankees had announced a news conference with Rodriguez to be held before Sunday’s game against the Cleveland Indians.

headline: How an Iranian’s Spy Saga Ends, 6 Years Later: He’s Executed
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Defectors (Political)', 'Capital Punishment', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In 2010, Shahram Amiri, a scientist, claimed on YouTube that the C.I.A. had kidnapped him. A subsequent video changed the narrative. Missing his son, he returned to Iran and disappeared.
lead_paragraph: When Shahram Amiri emerged from the shadows into the spotlight six years ago, he was a young Iranian scientist who suddenly appeared on YouTube from a safe house, telling a bizarre story of having been kidnapped by the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: Ichiro Suzuki Reaches 3,000 Hits, Again Breaking Ground for Japanese Players
abstract: Suzuki accomplished the feat in his 16th Major League Baseball season, joining only Pete Rose as players who did so that quickly.
lead_paragraph: Ichiro Suzuki, the baseball pioneer who proved 15 years ago that Japanese hitters could succeed in Major League Baseball, reached a hallowed milestone Sunday when he became the 30th player to compile 3,000 hits.

headline: Amazon Has Big Plans for Alexa: Running the ‘Star Trek’ Home
keywords: ['Home Automation and Smart Homes', 'Wireless Communications', 'Speakers (Audio)', 'Voice Recognition Systems']
abstract: The tech giant wants to weave its intelligent assistant into other smart gadgets, even those not made by Amazon. But weakness in mobile could be an obstacle.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon surprised a lot of people when its Echo, a $180 so-called smart speaker, became a hit, giving them a novel way to play music, turn on the lights in their homes and set thermostats with voice commands.

headline: Expulsions of Protesters at Rio Olympics Draw Rebukes
abstract: Several fans wearing T-shirts critical of Brazil’s interim president were shown being removed from a women’s soccer match.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The expulsions of ticket holders from Olympic sites after they protested Michel Temer, Brazil’s interim president, is fueling a debate over the limits of freedom of expression in a country that remains on edge amid a period of extraordinary political upheaval.

headline: Colorado Fracking Limit Deadline; Valeant and Disney Earnings Reports
abstract: Signatures are due Monday to put proposals on Colorado’s ballot that would restrict hydraulic fracturing; and attention turns to earnings at Valeant, Disney and Macy’s.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what to expect in the week ahead.

headline: ‘This Is Your Brain on Drugs,’ Tweaked for Today’s Parents
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Marijuana', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting']
abstract: Children of the 1980s will remember the sizzling egg equated to a brain on drugs. Its coming back helps those same people talk to their own children.
lead_paragraph: For a generation of commercial-watching adolescents, it was an indelible image: an egg, sizzling in a frying pan, representing “your brain on drugs.” It was a straightforward message, and the ad’s final line — “Any questions?” — asked as the egg white clouded and cooked, was strictly rhetorical.

headline: Alex Rodriguez’s Orchestrated Move May Not Be His Last
abstract: He talked of being “at peace” in stepping aside as a player, but the allure of records so close could tug at the achievement-obsessed Yankee.
lead_paragraph: This is how it ends for Alex Rodriguez? With a Yankees-orchestrated whimper instead of an all-out public relations war?

headline: South Korean Missile Defense Deal Appears to Sour China’s Taste for K-Pop
keywords: ['Television', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Music', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: In the wake of a Korean military agreement with the United States, several events in China featuring the South’s music and television stars have been canceled.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Has K-pop become one of the first victims of a recent fraying of relations between China and South Korea?

headline: Left Behind on Billionaire’s Row
abstract: Wondering what will happen to the homeless people who cluster each morning on West 57th Street, as developers compete to build the highest condominium building.
lead_paragraph: My commute to work includes a walk on West 57th Street (a.k.a. Billionaire’s Row), a street laced with new high-rise condominiums and others under construction. A competition seems to be in progress: Which will be the highest and most expensive?

headline: Erdogan Seizes Failed Coup in Turkey as a Chance to Supplant Ataturk
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Muslims and Islam', 'Propaganda']
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is racing to banish the legacy of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk and establish himself and Islam as the most consequential factors in modern Turkish history.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has always had ambitions of surpassing Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkey, as the country’s most consequential figure.

headline: A Maoist’s Burden in Nepal
abstract: It’s a moment of reckoning for a legendary former guerrilla leader, and new prime minister.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Ten summers ago in Nepal, the Maoist leader Pushpa Kamal Dahal emerged from hiding just as the decade-long insurgency he had directed was pushing the country’s monarchy to its knees. The rebel chief was picked up by a government helicopter, then whisked to the prime minister’s residence in Kathmandu to begin official peace talks.

headline: Heng on Thailand’s Military Referendum
abstract: No matter the outcome of Sunday’s national referendum on a new constitution, the junta will remain in control until it decides to hand power back to an elected government.
lead_paragraph: No matter the outcome of Sunday’s national referendum, the junta will remain in control until it decides to hand power back to an elected government.

headline: How to Give Rural America Broadband? Look to the Early 1900s
keywords: ['Rural Areas', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Fiber Optics', 'Cooperatives', 'Electric Light and Power', "New Deal (1930's)"]
abstract: To provide high-speed internet to remote areas, local power companies are borrowing techniques that were used to electrify towns in the United States nearly a century ago.
lead_paragraph: ZENA, Okla. — From the sofa in his living room, Clinton Creason can see the electric pole outside that his father staked 70 years ago to bring power to this remote area of hilly cattle pastures.

headline: Once Taunted by Steve Jobs, Companies Are Now Big Customers of Apple
keywords: ['Enterprise Computing', 'Mobile Applications', 'iPhone', 'iPad', 'Corporations', 'Handheld Computers', 'Tablet Computers', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Corporations are turning to Apple’s products for their tight-knit hardware and software, advanced security and intuitive interfaces.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the primordial days of computing, IBM machines were so common inside corporations that there was a running joke in the industry: Nobody ever got fired for buying IBM.

headline: Township Saw a Zoning Issue. The Justice Dept. Saw Religious Discrimination.
abstract: As anti-Islamic rhetoric and discrimination surge, the federal government is emerging as a bulwark in defense of embattled American Muslims.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For nearly 10 months, a Muslim congregation in the Philadelphia suburb of Bensalem, Pa., pleaded with township officials to allow the construction of a mosque, paying for expensive traffic studies, repeatedly explaining Islamic practices, revising and re-revising design plans, and then receiving the final word: No.

headline: Security Force of 85,000 Fills Rio, Unsettling Rights Activists
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2016)', 'Police', 'Muggings', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: Incidents, including a mugging of a security chief and an assault on a Portuguese official, are piling up, while the show of force has raised concerns about overly aggressive policing.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — If battling pickpockets were an Olympic sport at the current Summer Games, the Brazilian authorities might qualify for a medal.

headline: TV Networks Try to Win Over the Critics
abstract: At an industry event in Beverly Hills, television executives try to make the case that their shows stand out.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — With the number of scripted television shows swelling each year — there were more than 400 last year, and that number is expected to go up this year — anxious network executives are once again attending a news media event here to make the case that their stuff is just a wee bit better than the next guy’s.

headline: After Ailes and Cosby, a Moment for More Women to Speak Up
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes', 'Discrimination', 'Workplace Environment', 'Women and Girls', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: High-profile accusations have drawn new attention to sexual harassment and assault, but the risks of reporting incidents still discourage women from coming forward.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 1991, an obscure law professor named Anita Hill pushed the issue of sexual harassment into the public consciousness when she accused her former boss, the Supreme Court nominee Clarence Thomas, of having repeatedly made lewd overtures toward her.

headline: Neil Walker and Michael Conforto Homer as Mets Top Tigers
abstract: Walker’s two-run shot in the ninth inning decided the game after Jacob deGrom held host Detroit to one run over six and two-thirds innings.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Neil Walker had someplace to go Sunday afternoon. His wife, Niki, is expected to deliver their first child next week, and Walker needed to drive about four and a half hours to spend Monday’s day off with her at their home near Pittsburgh.

headline: Trump Is Testing the Norms of Objectivity in Journalism
abstract: As Donald J. Trump continues his stream of outrageous and disquieting statements, journalists must grapple with how to cover him — and if, or when, to abandon the rules of traditional reporting.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a working journalist and you believe that Donald J. Trump is a demagogue playing to the nation’s worst racist and nationalistic tendencies, that he cozies up to anti-American dictators and that he would be dangerous with control of the United States nuclear codes, how the heck are you supposed to cover him?

headline: A Nuclear Legacy Within Reach
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Editorials']
abstract: President Obama still can and should take steps to advance his vision of a safer world.
lead_paragraph: The Air Force has formally begun the process of asking defense contractors to submit proposals for a new long-range cruise missile and a new land-based intercontinental ballistic missile. These two weapons, capable of carrying nuclear payloads, will cost billions of dollars. The first is unnecessary; the second, debatable.

headline: At 82, Emperor Akihito of Japan Wants to Retire. Will Japan Let Him?
abstract: The emperor spoke publicly for the first time about retiring, saying he feared it would become “more difficult” to fulfill his duties.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Japanese have acknowledged that their emperor is not a god and he has been stripped of all political power, but the nation still views its monarch as so central to the sense of identity that he is not permitted to resign.

headline: Ivo Pitanguy, Plastic Surgeon to the Stars and a Celebrity Himself, Dies at 93
abstract: Dr. Pitanguy established himself in Brazil as one of the world’s most famous plastic surgeons, as much through his marketing savvy as through his surgical skills.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Ivo Pitanguy, a pioneering Brazilian plastic surgeon who performed face lifts, tummy tucks and other procedures on the rich, famous and royal, becoming rich, famous and celebrated in his own right, died on Saturday at his home in Rio de Janeiro. He was 93.

headline: Elliot Tiber, Who With a Permit Brought Forth Woodstock, Dies at 81
abstract: As the head of a Chamber of Commerce, Mr. Tiber, an unlikely counterculture hero, offered a home for the music festival. He wrote two memoirs.
lead_paragraph: In July 1969, the town of Wallkill, N.Y., dealt a potentially mortal blow to Woodstock Ventures, a group of rookie promoters hoping to organize a grand festival of rock music in rural New York.

headline: ‘The Night Of’ Season 1, Episode 5: Seeing Naz in a New Light
abstract: There have been hints of Naz’s hardening resolve, but we are suddenly confronted with the thought that our hero may not be innocent after all.
lead_paragraph: In Jacques Audiard’s superb 2009 thriller “A Prophet,” a French teenager of Algerian descent begins serving a six-year sentence for attacking police officers, but quickly discovers that he has no allies in prison. Needing protection in order to survive, he carries out a soul-coarsening atrocity on behalf of a Corsican mob boss who runs a criminal operation within the prison walls. By committing this heinous act of violence, however, he crosses a moral Rubicon that forever changes him and the audience follows his transformation into a vicious, calculating gangster. He enters prison a lamb and leaves a lion.

headline: Review: A Femme Fatale, a Private Eye and Dorm Mates, at Summer Shorts
abstract: Uneasy relationships feature in the three one-act plays in Series B of this 59E59 Theaters festival.
lead_paragraph: By the time things turn dizzily theatrical, in a noir-style romp called “The Dark Clothes of Night,” the audience is well primed. This delicious little play, by Richard Alfredo, is the third of three one-acts in Series B of this year’s Summer Shorts festival at 59E59 Theaters, and it’s the first that feels unmistakably like a work for the stage — dressed up though it is as a love letter to classic cinema.

headline: As Alex Rodriguez Prepares to Retire, Fans Grapple With a Complicated Legacy
abstract: On Sunday, Rodriguez announced that Friday would be his final game with the Yankees, closing a career that has made fans awe at his ability and criticize his actions.
lead_paragraph: In the moments after Alex Rodriguez announced that Friday would be the end of his turbulent yet stellar playing career, fans outside Yankee Stadium on Sunday cheered for different reasons — some in relief, and others in solidarity with a player they will always consider one of the greats.

headline: Katie Ledecky Smashes Her Own World Record in 400 Freestyle
abstract: Another day, another milestone for Katie Ledecky, who won her second medal, and first gold, of the Rio Games on Sunday night in the 400-meter freestyle.
lead_paragraph: After finishing, having roared through the last 50 meters of the 400-meter freestyle at a sprinter’s pace, Katie Ledecky turned around to see the scoreboard. It told her what she surely already knew: she had won gold, her first of the Rio Games, and she had crushed her own world record.

headline: Novak Djokovic Upset in First Round by Juan Martín del Potro
abstract: The Williams sisters were also eliminated early at the Olympic Games.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Novak Djokovic, the world’s dominant tennis player, had made the Olympic gold medal in singles one of his big priorities for 2016.

headline: Brooklyn Church, Over a Century Old, Likely to Make Way for Affordable Housing
abstract: After a series of clashes with preservationists, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn filed an application to demolish a church built in 1908 by Italian immigrants.
lead_paragraph: A seven-year battle between preservationists and the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn over the fate of a church more than a century old will likely end with the arrival of a wrecking ball.

headline: Trial by Jury, a Hallowed American Right, Is Vanishing
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Legal Profession', 'Jury System', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Plea Bargaining']
abstract: Far fewer cases in recent decades are going to jury trials, as prosecutors are increasingly negotiating plea deals, a trend that some say disrupts a foundation of the American justice system.
lead_paragraph: The criminal trial ended more than two and a half years ago, but Judge Jesse M. Furman can still vividly recall the case. It stands out, not because of the defendant or the subject matter, but because of its rarity: In his four-plus years on the bench in Federal District Court in Manhattan, it was his only criminal jury trial.

headline: Competition, in a Swirl of Color
abstract: On the second full day of events at the 2016 Summer Games in Rio de Janeiro, foils flashed, water splashed, bodies crashed and horses dashed.
lead_paragraph: On the second full day of events at the 2016 Summer Games in Rio de Janeiro, foils flashed, water splashed, bodies crashed and horses dashed.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, August 8, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “It’s hugely disappointing. A trial is the one place where the system really gets tested. Everything else is done behind closed doors.”

headline: Simone Biles Has Just One Peer in Rio, but Rejects the Comparison
abstract: At 19, Biles is considered the best female gymnast in history, but she still looks up to Kohei Uchimura, 27.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — In the hours before the preliminary round of Olympic gymnastics, members of the United States women’s team were at the cafeteria in the athletes’ village, goofing around. Telling jokes. Making funny faces. Laughing so hard that Martha Karolyi, the women’s national team coordinator, approached Aly Raisman, the team captain, to tell them to quiet down.

headline: Michael Phelps Powers U.S. to Victory in 4x100 Relay, Winning a 19th Gold
abstract: Phelps won his 23rd Olympic medal over all for the United States, extending his record.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Michael Phelps won his 19th Olympic gold medal as the United States won the 4x100 relay at the Olympics on Sunday. The Americans’ traditional rival in the event, France, was second, and Australia third.

headline: Russia Not Allowed to Compete in Paralympics
abstract: An official called the government-coordinated cover-up of doping among Russia’s top disabled athletes “abominable.”
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Paralympics officials have done what Olympics officials chose not to do, barring all Russian athletes from their Games after an elaborate cheating scheme.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Hitchcock/Truffaut’ and Michael Phelps at the Rio Olympics
abstract: “Hitchcock/Truffaut” looks back at the directors’ 1962 meeting of the minds. And Michael Phelps swims the 200-meter butterfly at the Rio Olympics.
lead_paragraph: “Hitchcock/Truffaut” recalls the directors’ 1962 meeting of the minds. Michael Phelps swims a signature event, the 200-meter butterfly, at the Rio Olympics. And Michael Shannon glowers as an outlaw on the lam with an unusual child in “Midnight Special.”

headline: Landslides in Mexico Kill at Least 39 After Rains From Tropical Storm Earl
abstract: Record-breaking rains in the eastern states of Puebla and Veracruz caused landslides heavy enough to bury entire homes, the government said.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — At least 39 people have died in Mexico after a series of landslides caused by torrential rains from Tropical Storm Earl, government officials said, as the country braced for the arrival of another tropical storm.

headline: 5 Things to Know About Japan’s Emperor and Imperial Family
abstract: The oldest continuous monarchy in the world, extending back to 600 B.C., has had an unbroken hereditary line of 125 emperors.
lead_paragraph: Emperor Akihito of Japan indicated in a rare public address on Monday that he wants to abdicate the throne, which would make him the first Japanese monarch in 200 years to step down. Here are five essential facts about one of the world’s oldest and most cloistered royal families.

headline: Moving Beyond Bratton
abstract: The departing police commissioner William J. Bratton brought important innovations to New York. But the time has come to try new ideas.
lead_paragraph: WITH the impending departure of William J. Bratton as commissioner of the New York Police Department, an important chapter in American policing is about to close. Mr. Bratton — with whom I have collaborated in a Harvard program on police reform — has served with distinction as commissioner in Boston, Los Angeles and twice in New York, the nation’s largest department and a trendsetter in the profession. Not surprisingly, police chiefs across the country are watching the Police Department closely to see whether, and how, it moves beyond Mr. Bratton’s policies.

headline: A Message to a Stingy Governor
keywords: ['Public Defenders and Court-Appointed Lawyers (Criminal)', 'Public Defenders and Court-Appointed Lawyers (Criminal)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Editorials']
abstract: Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri, by slashing the budget for public defenders, has turned a blind eye to a pressing need in his state.
lead_paragraph: Considering the hard-pressed criminal justice system of Missouri — a crisis laid bare by the police shooting and civil unrest in Ferguson in 2014 — the last thing Gov. Jay Nixon should be doing is stinting on support of the state public defender system, which provides counsel to indigent defendants.

headline: Can Clinton or Trump Recapture Robust American Growth?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Income Inequality', 'Productivity', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Taxation', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Gross National Product (GNP)']
abstract: Voters expect a president to improve their lives, but the cause of anxiety follows trends that are decades in the making.
lead_paragraph: The party conventions were rightly characterized as either relentlessly downbeat (Republican) or fervently optimistic (Democratic). The Republican view rests in part on poll numbers that show a solid majority of Americans think that the country is headed in the wrong direction. What has caused this malaise?

headline: Time to Borrow
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Credit and Debt', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: The overwhelming case for deficit spending.
lead_paragraph: The campaign still has three ugly months to go, but the odds — 83 percent odds, according to the New York Times’s model — are that it will end with the election of a sane, sensible president. So what should she do to boost America’s economy, which is doing better than most of the world but is still falling far short of where it should be?

headline: Many Countries Will Need Help Adapting to Climate Change
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Editorials']
abstract: Rich nations need to make good on their pledges, particularly to low-lying island nations whose very existence is threatened.
lead_paragraph: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported last week that global temperatures last year were the highest on record — and that this year is likely to be hotter still. That is a powerful reason for rich countries to begin making good on their promises to help low-lying island nations, some of the poorest countries in the world, build their defenses against the disastrous effects of climate change, which some are already experiencing.

headline: Trump’s Troubles in the Black Belt
abstract: Signs of Republican decline, even in the Deep South.
lead_paragraph: There has been much talk this election about the fundamental transformation of voters in the Rust Belt and what that portends for Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump.

headline: Can We Trust Julian Assange and WikiLeaks?
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'E-Mail']
abstract: The D.N.C. emails were in the public interest but they also show how reckless and agenda-driven WikiLeaks has become.
lead_paragraph: The release of a cache of emails from the Democratic National Committee by WikiLeaks last month has raised a great many questions — about the role of the D.N.C. in trying to influence the primary and about the alleged interference of Russian intelligence in an American election.

headline: New Approaches to Fighting Cancer
abstract: Doctors discuss the promise of immunotherapy but worry about giving false hope; a cancer patient believes the treatment helped save his life.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Against ‘Sustainability’
abstract: The truth is we “sustain” nature to preserve the resources needed for our own consumption.
lead_paragraph: Among the many stories that can be told about the origins of the environmental movement in the West, perhaps the most common is that it began with the emergence of Romanticism in the late 18th century. In this version, environmentalism was born as the good twin to evil industrialization. Today, when we talk about ecological sustainability and environmental preservation, we typically still understand them in terms of a battle between nature and industry.

headline: Listening to the Voices From Hijabi World
abstract: On what is likely the most diverse college campus in the United States, Muslim women who wear a hijab talk about their lives.
lead_paragraph: To set foot on the campus of Rutgers University, Newark, is to witness a majority-minority census in three dimensions. Brown, black, beige and every shade in between, the university’s population is robust with first-generation Americans redefining attitudes about race, interfaith dialogue and national identity. Those features have led it to be ranked by U.S. News and World Report as the most diverse campus in the United States.

headline: Kenya Angers Taiwan by Deporting More Fraud Suspects to China

headline: The Import of the Antinori Wine Family in a Terra Cotta Relief
abstract: At the Brooklyn Museum since 1898, it is restored and on display in Boston and Washington, D.C.

As testimony to their importance during the Renaissance, a massive glazed terra-cotta relief, “The Resurrection of Christ,” by Giovanni della Robbia, dating from around 1524 and commissioned by the Antinoris, is a highlight of an exhibition of della Robbia works at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. The relief, in a half-moon shape, was created for the entrance to one of the family’s properties and includes the Antinori crest, designed by della Robbia. Since 1898 it has been in the Brooklyn Museum. The Antinoris contributed to the restoration of the work: “Della Robbia: Sculpting With Color in Renaissance Florence,” Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, to Dec. 4; National Gallery of Art, Washington, Feb. 4 to June 4, 2017.

headline: Pretty Girls Are Supposed to Smile
abstract: I was born with Moebius syndrome, a rare form of facial paralysis that leaves me unable to smile.
lead_paragraph: “There is no one who has not smiled at least once,” writes Marianne LaFrance, a Yale University psychology professor, in her 2011 book “Lip Service: Smiles in Life, Death, Trust, Lies, Work, Memory, Sex and Politics.” Her book explores how smiling unifies us. Like breath, the smile is universal. We smile to connect, to forgive, to love. A smile is beauty, human.

headline: Delta Malfunction on Land Keeps a Fleet of Planes From the Sky

headline: A Vote for Change in South Africa

The vote could presage major political change when South Africans go to the polls in national elections in 2019.

Costs could rise to the tens of millions of dollars if the case goes to trial.

headline: Mike Pence Should Get Donald Trump to Withdraw
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: Governor Pence should either persuade his embattled running mate to exit the race or step aside himself.
lead_paragraph: For the past year, every effort by Republican leaders to topple Donald J. Trump has met with embarrassing failure. Yet, according to published reports, jittery insiders have been considering still other ways of detaching the Trump brand from the party of Lincoln. The best option is one that can avoid an ugly, and likely futile, confrontation and help both Mr. Trump and his party save face. All eyes must now turn to his running mate, Mike Pence, to do what must be done.

headline: Brand to Know: Traditional Soap, Made Modern
abstract: In Toronto, Binu Binu makes sculptural bars packed with nourishing oils that take inspiration from the Korean bathhouse.
lead_paragraph: A Korean body scrub is a spa experience not easily forgotten — the intensely exfoliating rubdown requires a certain amount of grit and courage. For the Toronto native Karen Kim, 36, the memory of her Korean grandmother buffing her body when she was 5 years old left a lasting impression: “The vigor and determination!” she says of the sloughing technique. “It was painful but effective.” Years later, when she was in her 20s, Kim traveled to Seok Mo Do, a fishing island off the coast of South Korea, with her mother and five aunts. Most days revolved around trips to the public baths and cleansing rituals. “Every morning, we’d take our sponges and buckets, and sit in the bath all day,” she says. “My Korean isn’t very good, so it was hard to communicate, but this was an intimate bonding moment.”

headline: Review: A Musical Tale of the Cosmos, Birth and Death
abstract: “The Hubble Cantata,” by Paola Prestini, fuses music with virtual reality to take the audience through the mysteries of space.
lead_paragraph: Within the life span of our galaxy, the premiere of Paola Prestini’s “The Hubble Cantata” at the Prospect Park Bandshell on Saturday night barely registers as a blip. And yet its 50 minutes of ponderous texts set to fluffy nebulae of diatonic music sometimes felt endless.

headline: Review: ‘Powerhouse’ Lifts Veil on Secretive Hollywood Agency
abstract: For a look inside Creative Artists Agency, the author has simply organized more than 700 pages of raw interviews in more or less chronological order.
lead_paragraph: With the fall of the studio system, when actors labored under long-term employment contracts, came the rise of the talent agents, those mysterious professionals whose job is to procure employment for artists. The mystery extends from what agents actually do to the economics of the agencies where they work, as all the major industry players are private and notoriously secretive. In “Powerhouse: The Untold Story of Hollywood’s Creative Artists Agency,” James Andrew Miller has taken on the formidable task of lifting the veil on the sector.

abstract: The health care journalist Mike King examines the increasingly precarious state of the nation’s public hospitals, and the stinginess that threatens them.
lead_paragraph: All hospitals deliver an endless loop of drama. In America’s great public hospitals, the show is nothing short of operatic.

headline: Monkeys That Smile the Way We Do
abstract: A recent study shows that seven baby Japanese macaques spontaneously smiled a combined 58 times while they were sleeping.
lead_paragraph: Need a laugh? Get online and take a look at videos of baby Japanese macaques smiling as they sleep.

headline: Making the Harpsichord Modern Again
abstract: Mahan Esfahani, who performed at the Mostly Mozart Festival on Friday, is trying to transform the instrument’s stereotypical image as an early-music staple.
lead_paragraph: “Playing the harpsichord is my best expression of me liking my life,” said Mahan Esfahani, 32, sipping peppermint tea at a restaurant near Lincoln Center before his stimulating late-night appearance at the Mostly Mozart Festival on Friday. “I am a harpsichordist because I have to make a living, but if anything it’s a tool to look at everything else.”

headline: A Brain Surgeon’s Legacy Through a Grandson’s Eyes
keywords: ['Brain', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Books and Literature', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Memory']

lead_paragraph: As a boy growing up in Massachusetts, Luke Dittrich revered his grandfather, a brain surgeon whose home was full of exotic instruments. Later, he learned that he was not only a prominent doctor but had played a significant role in modern medical history.

headline: The Opening Ceremony Founders on the Importance of 1993
abstract: Humberto Leon and Carol Lim have collaborated with Calvin Klein on a T-shirt of a Kate Moss ad from that year — and reminisce about the decade with T.
lead_paragraph: The Opening Ceremony founders Humberto Leon and Carol Lim agree that 1993 was a formative year. For one, they both graduated from suburban Los Angeles high schools. “That summer was pivotal,” Lim says. “I could really enjoy myself because I’d gotten into college, so I backpacked through Europe for four months.” And that fall, they enrolled at University of California, Berkeley, where they met and, Leon recalls, quickly bonded over their shared affinity for polyester outfits. “At the time, we looked to magazines and what our favorite actors and musicians were wearing,” he remembers. “As an 18-year-old kid, you’re trying to emulate the people you admire.” In the pre-internet era, the pair had to conduct nondigital “research,” as Lim calls it — queuing for the latest issue of Interview or the Face, or scrutinizing 10,000 Maniacs music videos.

headline: Review: ‘War Porn’ Widens the Field of Vision About the Costs in Iraq
abstract: Roy Scranton’s first novel builds on themes he has raised in essays, that focusing on the trauma of soldiers neglects the destruction they caused.
lead_paragraph: In a controversial essay published in the Los Angeles Review of Books in 2015, Roy Scranton, a United States Army veteran who served in Iraq, argued that our perception of war has been warped by modern war literature’s preoccupation with what he called “the trauma hero myth.”

Putin of Russia and his Turkish counterpart, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, are expected to reconsider their dispute over Syria at a meeting on Tuesday in St. Petersburg, with both leaders interested in a public display of affection to show the West that strained ties have not left them isolated.

It was the others — “you’re nothing, they’re out to get you, to kill you” — that led her down a rabbit hole of failed treatments and over a decade of hospitalizations, therapy and medications, all aimed at silencing those internal threats.

headline: Sorry, Ms. Jackson: You’re Underrated. ‘Control’ at 30
abstract: Thirty years after the release of her album “Control,” Janet Jackson remains essential to the development of pop and the integration of MTV.
lead_paragraph: The standard for planet-stopping artistic statements in pop music is now so high that you need a pilot’s license to compete with the Beyoncés, Kanyes and Kendricks of the world. But when Janet Jackson craved ascent, she didn’t go to flight school. She went to Flyte Tyme. That was the Minneapolis production company Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis operated and where the three came up with “Control,” Ms. Jackson’s third record and the first of their subtly strange, sonically complex thematic carnivals. The album turned 30 in February, peaked in popularity right about this time that year (hitting No. 1 in July) and still sounds today as much like 1986 as it does 2056. Some producers make hooks. These three made wedgies.

By this point, there had already been about 1,600 other Zika cases in the continental United States, but it soon became clear that this one was different.

This season has struggled, partly by aiming for network-drama polish rather than self-aware pulp. “Everlasting” is a show about people seeking triumph amid inescapable falsity; everything in “UnREAL” echoes that, with an edge. headline: The Return of the Gothic Lip
abstract: The latest iteration is more nostalgic indulgence than rebellious statement. But it still has a defiant power.
lead_paragraph: “Insensitive to red,” a heartbreaking phrase, is technically a description of early black-and-white film, which converted the colors of blood and red lipstick to black. Elsa Lanchester’s lips were painted redder than her auburn hair for 1935’s “The Bride of Frankenstein”; the makeup artist on the film based her look on a 3,300-year-old bust of Nefertiti, who announced her power by blackening her eyes, reddening her lips and dyeing her nails with dark henna. But when Lanchester appeared on screen as the Bride — “She’s alive!” — her overdrawn mouth looked dark as hell: Et voilà, the modern gothic lip was born. Robert Smith of the Cure, whose lipstick emphasized not the Cupid’s bow but the corners of his mouth, giving him the moue of a dissatisfied cannibal, was said to inspire the almost-black “goth lip” of the 1990s; he only, in fact, wore the ’60s designer Mary Quant’s Crimson Scorcher. But what are facts when it comes to what we see? Color depends on perception, and our perception, so dependent on lighting, changes over the years the way light does over the course of a day. Sometimes we’re desensitized to red, and so to get a look as fresh as red lipstick used to give, we turn to shades that look more like ink.

(From the first book: “Corrine was getting so tired of parties: dinner parties, birthday parties, pre-publication parties, housewarming parties; holiday and theme and opening-night parties, closing-night parties.…”) He followed them through the crisis of 9/11. And now he is back to watch them reach 50 and hit amplified fiscal, marital and existential crises.

headline: Redefining Hawaiian Fine Dining
abstract: An ambitious new restaurant in Honolulu’s still pleasantly seedy Chinatown is serving small plates that re-envision the islands’ staples.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Hawaii’s high-end restaurants have been dominated by outsiders. At first glance, Senia, serving ambitious small plates in Honolulu’s still pleasantly seedy Chinatown, might seem like more of the same: It’s co-owned by the chef Anthony Rush, a Brit who arrived from London mere months ago. But Rush’s partner is Chris Kajioka, a Honolulu native with intimate knowledge of local ingredients. Together the chefs, who met working at Per Se, have created a menu that centers on the islands’ most elemental staples, re-envisioned as haute cuisine. Red snapper, which in Hawaii is often served simply with ginger and soy sauce, is baked in a sourdough crust and cracked tableside; backyard fruits like mountain apples and guavas are prepared with traditional French techniques; and lowly starches like taro, sweet potatoes and breadfruit are given center stage. “This is not meant to be intellectual food,” Kajioka says. “We really want to represent Hawaii — just in a different way.”

headline: Let the Emperor Retire
abstract: Emperor Akihito’s oblique appeal poses a problem for Japanese politicians.
lead_paragraph: It says a lot about Japan’s constitutional monarchy that Emperor Akihito, 82 and in failing health, would be stepping out of bounds if he were to say he wanted to retire. Under the Constitution laid down by the victorious United States after World War II, the emperor’s role is strictly restricted to being the “symbol of the state and of the unity of the people,” and since the law says the monarch rules until he dies, to utter words like “abdicate” or even “retire” would be seen as a forbidden sortie into politics. Yet in a televised address on Monday remarkable for its circumlocution, the emperor was clear about what he couldn’t say. And if it wasn’t clear, we’ll say it for him: He’d really, really like to retire.

A neighborhood once dominated by printers and reporters, all working and (more often) drinking within half a mile of one another, has become the haunt of lawyers, insurers and other soulless creatures.

headline: The Most Dangerous Eight Seconds in Sports, on ‘Fearless’
abstract: The Netflix documentary series, debuting Aug. 19, focuses on professional bull riding.
lead_paragraph: If bull riding were an Olympic event, the Brazilians might sweep the medals and win bonus points for bravery. Adriano Moraes, Ednei Caminhas, Guilherme Marchi, Renato Nunes and Silvano Alves: Each has been a world champion of what are considered the most dangerous eight seconds in sports. “Fearless,” a Netflix documentary series debuting Friday, Aug. 19, depicts wiry cowboys straddling tornadoes of muscle, horn and hoof more than 10 times their weight and hanging on as if their existence depended on it.

lead_paragraph: The stage for the Battery Dance Festival, in its 35th year, faces spectacular views of New York’s harbor. That’s appropriate as the free performances there this summer include 35 companies, 38 choreographers and an estimated 160 performers who embrace the world.

headline: Atlanta Rappers Join Fool’s Gold Day Off Party
abstract: Migos and Lil Yachty are among the acts scheduled to perform at this event in Manhattan. Local rappers are also on the bill.
lead_paragraph: Two distinct tangents of Atlanta’s flamboyant, overflowing rap scene will take over the Manhattan waterfront on Saturday, Aug. 20: Migos, the three-headed hydra of euphoric, rapid-fire catchphrases, and Lil Yachty, the self-proclaimed “king of the teens,” with his singsong flow and constantly bouncing red-beaded braids. Both will bring the joyful youth contingent to the seventh annual Fool’s Gold Day Off party, which also features the promising local rappers Leaf, Meyhem Lauren and Dave East.

headline: Collector Helper at Anthony Philip Fine Art
abstract: More than 140 works by 35 artists, each one priced under $750, will be featured at this Brooklyn gallery.
lead_paragraph: Part of the mission of Anthony Philip Fine Art in Bushwick, Brooklyn, is to connect emerging artists with aspiring collectors. So the gallery’s latest show, opening Friday, Aug. 12, aims specifically at young and novice collectors. “Life Sized: A Small Works Invitational” features more than 140 artworks that are under 12 inches by 12 inches and priced under $750. “Our hope is that there will be something here for anyone looking to jump-start their collection,” Mr. Philip said. The 35 artists in the show work in a range of media, including painting, sculpture, photography, abstract art and traditional drawing. Among them are Kristen Balouch, Jonathan Quinn and Tariku Shiferaw from New York; Amy Lottes, Jeff Kapfer and Barb Flunker from Missouri; and artists from Kansas, South Carolina and Washington. (Through Sept. 3; anthonyphilipfineart.com.)

headline: In the Garden, With Strings, at the Noguchi Museum

The museum has a partnership with the new-music collective Bang on a Can, which on Sunday, Aug. 14, brings the American Contemporary Music Ensemble to the garden. On the program are string quartets by Philip Glass and Meredith Monk as well as the premiere of a cello solo by Caleb Burhans, played by Clarice Jensen, the ensemble’s artistic director. (3 p.m., 718-204-7088, noguchi.org.)

headline: ‘Pioneers of African-American Cinema’: Black Filmmaking Aborning

headline: The Comic Nikki Glaser at Carolines on Broadway
abstract: The star of “Not Safe With Nikki Glaser” on Comedy Central will headline six shows, beginning on Thursday, Aug. 18.
lead_paragraph: The dynamic stand-up comic Nikki Glaser has produced a popular podcast, co-hosted a short-lived talk show on MTV and starred in several memorable sketches on “Inside Amy Schumer.” But the best example of her wry and raunchy sense of humor may be in “Not Safe With Nikki Glaser,” a cheerfully sex-obsessed series on Comedy Central. The show, which includes high-concept videos that take her places like a porn shoot (where she feeds lines to actors) and a foot fetish party, helps Ms. Glaser come off as forever game, if also a little startled by her own chutzpah. This tension between her bluntness and her anxiety has long been the engine fueling her charismatic, assured stand-up, the bedrock of her prolific young career. She headlines six shows at Carolines on Broadway, starting on Thursday, Aug. 18. (212-757-4100, carolines.com.)

headline: Even Superheroes Punch the Clock
abstract: Many of summer’s tentpole movies (“Suicide Squad,” “Star Trek Beyond”) offer workplace allegories, with rivalries and power plays.
lead_paragraph: In summertime, you can count on two things. There will be a lot of sequels and reboots in theaters, and there will be a lot of critics complaining about that. It’s just part of the job. And after 2015, when a handful of reboots and sequels landed on Top 10 lists, we’re back to a familiar routine. The movies range from pretty good to outright terrible, they open to mixed reviews and big box-office numbers, and before we know it, the Oscar race is heating up. headline: Weight Lifting Her Way From Fiji to Rio
abstract: An island-ravaging cyclone hasn’t been able to keep the lifter Apolonia Vaivai from competing in the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: On a Wednesday morning in July, the weight lifter Apolonia Vaivai leaned against the cinder-block wall of a crowded bus stall in the South Pacific port city of Suva, Fiji. Vaivai, who is 25 and just over five feet tall and thick with muscle, was wearing turquoise workout shorts and a matching T-shirt and cap bearing a Monster energy-drink logo that covered the tips of her ears. She had come to town to arrange a visa for the Rio Olympic Games, even though she was not yet sure if she was going. Fiji had earned one spot in the women’s weight lifting program, but Weightlifting Fiji, the country’s governing body for the sport, had yet to reveal who would fill it. Rather than wait in Suva for the announcement, Vaivai decided to make the jarring, four-hour bus-and-ferry trip home to Ovalau, a nearby island. “In three days,” she told me later on the ferry, “I’ll find out if I’m going to the Olympics.”

Chris Christie of New Jersey lied to reporters when he said he did not believe any senior member of his staff knew about the plot to block traffic to the George Washington Bridge, one of his aides told a colleague in a text message included in a federal court filing on Wednesday.

headline: One Artist’s Very Symbolic New Work, Explained — Sort of
abstract: Ryan McGinness breaks down some of the iconography in his striking series of “Signals” paintings.
lead_paragraph: The paintings in the artist Ryan McGinness’s new series, “Signals,” immediately invite interpretation — and then, just as quickly, elude it. Each of the pieces is a circular wood panel, 18 inches in diameter and ringed by a thick red outline. Inside are a handful of stark, graphic black-and-white symbols (a bomb with a seedling sprouting from it; a string tied around a middle finger) that strongly evoke meaning, without giving it all away. “They use the visual language of universal sign systems and therefore give the illusion that they are communicating blunt pedestrian information,” McGinness notes, “but they undermine that same visual language by evading elucidation.”

headline: Five Places to Go in Bali
abstract: This peaceful haven for expat surfers has lately seen an uptick in hip new options like vegan cafes, music bars and housewares shops.
lead_paragraph: Tucked between beaches and rolling green rice paddies north of the flashy tourist hub of Seminyak, the bohemian enclave of Canggu (pronounced “CHANG-oo”) has always lived below the radar. A peaceful haven for expat surfers, Canggu’s mellow vibe and surf breaks have been luring backpack-toting travelers since the ’80s. Recently however, hip new options including vegan cafes, music bars and housewares shops have sprouted among the local staples like Old Man’s bar, Betelnut Café and Deus Ex Machina, a cafe and motorcycle shop. After vintage USA Network bumpers touting the “Word Up Wednesday” programming block on “America’s Favorite TV Network” roll, we suddenly see Mr. Malek’s Elliot Alderson dropped into an 1980s family sitcom, with all the VHS picture quality and canned laughter that entails. headline: The Latest in Science Fiction and Fantasy
abstract: Planetary destruction and other uses of mathematics in a far-future society; women in geekdom; and shapeshifters who prey on humans in the Mughal Empire, and today.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to get lost in the kaleidoscopic world-­building of NINEFOX GAMBIT (Solaris, paper, $9.99), the first ­novel by the well-regarded story writer Yoon Ha Lee. Lee submerges readers without explanation into the hexarchate — a star-spanning far-future society whose culture relies on advanced mathematics to produce “exotic effects” that are nigh magical. A sort of unearthly physics, these can make select individuals functionally immortal, even as exotic generators churn forth monstrous ­vector-scrambling storms that disintegrate enemy soldiers down to component atoms. At the core of the technology is the high calendar. More than just a measurement of time, this calendar shapes the mathematical base of the exotic effects. Yet by changing the calendar and thus the underlying math of reality, dissidents can cripple hexarchate technology — a heresy to those in control, who punish dissenters by destroying them whole planets at a time. The disproportionate reprisals inevitably beget more heresy, so the hexarchate exists in a perpetual state of war in which it is too beneficially invested ever to end.

headline: The Anger of Cancer
abstract: Historically, the appearance of cancer was (wrongly) attributed to the repressed anger of patients. In fact, contagious rage is not the cause but may be an effect.
lead_paragraph: While dealing with lung cancer, my friend Nancy K. Miller seethed in her blog at pharmaceutical advertisements and hospital commercials that bombard us daily with pictures of joyous cancer patients supported by doting intimates. These jubilant characters have nothing to do with the frustrated people we know who periodically erupt in righteous indignation. I often must remind myself that anger needs to be understood as the flip side of the roiling fear that cancer instills in patients and also in caregivers.

These gelatinous, hermaphroditic sea creatures come in various shapes — eggs, ribbons and bells — and can be as short as a grain of rice or as long as a broomstick. They use their “combs,” rows of tiny paddlelike structures, to swim.

headline: Behind the Scenes of the Season’s Most Stylish Thriller
abstract: The fashion-photographer-turned-director Sean Ellis shares beautiful photos from the set of “Anthropoid.”
lead_paragraph: “I just don’t think period dramas work very well when they’re shot on the waxy, clean, sort of digital format,” says Sean Ellis, the director, co-writer and cinematographer of the new World War II thriller “Anthropoid.” “There’s too much detail, and it doesn’t feel real to me. Film is a little bit more forgiving and has a little bit more soul in it; there’s something beautiful in the grain.” Few would know better. As a fashion photographer, Ellis has shot for some of the world’s biggest brands and publications — among them Vogue, French Vogue and i-D — projects he prefers to capture the old-fashioned way. Ellis got his start with photography early on, after realizing the images in his head weren’t making it to paper when he tried to draw. “Something was lost in translation from my brain to my pen,” says Ellis. Instead, he photographed G.I. Joes, capturing imagined combat with the family camera.

When a version of that creature enters their world, the show unfolds into an interdimensional tribute to classic ’80s fantasy, sci-fi and horror, with nods to “Alien”; “E.T.: The Extraterrestrial”; “A Nightmare on Elm Street”; and Stephen King’s 1986 novel, “It.” Since its release in July, the series has attracted a wave of internet attention, with detailed examinations of its cinematic and cultural references — including a deep dive into the characters’ corduroy wardrobes.

headline: Wellness, Beauty and Style — According to a French Ballet Star
abstract: Aurélie Dupont, the new director of dance at the Paris Opera, shares her secrets.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Aurélie Dupont took over for Benjamin Millepied as director of dance at the Paris Opera — making her, in an industry that is still surprisingly male-dominated, one of the few women in the world directing a ballet company. Her credentials are impeccable: She’s a former étoile ballerina and was one of the most sought-after dancers in the world until ending her performance career in May 2015. As a dancer, Dupont called the Paris Opera home for 32 years — and with a 350-year-old legacy that makes it the oldest of its kind, the company is where ballet was born. But Dupont argues that in no way does this prevent it from remaining relevant to contemporary audiences. “Classical dance is an extraordinarily precise and physical art form,” she says. “It’s like a Chanel handbag — it endures through the generations. The old steps of ‘Swan Lake’ can be danced in ways which make them new. Just like your grandmother’s Chanel can be worn with sneakers in order to keep it modern.”

The Austrians driven beyond Gorizia are in more or less complete rout over an 18-kilometre front. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 12, 1891

lead_paragraph: Bill Miller, the veteran stock picker whose market-beating wisdom defined an earlier era of mutual fund dominance, split ways on Thursday with Legg Mason, his professional home for 35 years.

headline: Revisiting Michael Richards’s Art in the Age of Black Lives Matter
abstract: In the exhibition “Michael Richards: Winged,” his work exploring themes of aviation, flight and escape comes across in a new light.
lead_paragraph: Four white busts rest on pedestals with plaques that say, “When I was young I wanted to be a policeman.” They look as though they are wearing black masks; up close, it’s clear that the masks are really photographs of police brutality applied to the faces. A fifth bust, in the center, spins. A small image of Rodney King appears on its brow, like a target. This plaque is different: “A loss of faith brings vertigo.”

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It lacked the pageantry of the funeral nearly a year before, but when the body of Benjamin C. Bradlee, the longtime editor of The Washington Post, was reinterred in a Georgetown cemetery here last October, it had an air of permanence.

lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The International Monetary Fund has tentatively agreed to lend Egypt $12 billion in exchange for significant economic reforms, senior government finance officials said Thursday.

lead_paragraph: Washington — As a college student in Virginia, Corey Jacobs started selling drugs with the help of a group of friends to make some extra money. A Bronx native, Mr. Jacobs was no kingpin, and no aspect of their drug conspiracy involved violence. Now age 46, Mr. Jacobs has served 16 years of a sentence of life without parole in the federal system.

lead_paragraph: For years, Asuman Antepli, a nurse at a hospital in North Carolina , said people mostly just ignored the head-covering hijab she wears as a mark of her Muslim faith.

headline: STX, Hollywood Start-Up Behind ‘Bad Moms,’ Gains Chinese Investors
abstract: The conglomerates Tencent and PCCW join existing investors in the Hollywood company known for midbudget films.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — An upstart Hollywood company, STX Entertainment, said on Thursday that it had secured financing from two Chinese conglomerates, Tencent Holdings and PCCW, to further its ambitions in television, music and digital media.

headline: Defiant Toasts at the Gawker Wake
abstract: The site founded by Nick Denton looks toward the future the way it did at its inception: tweaking the establishment.
lead_paragraph: Since its beginning in 2002, Gawker has been a veritable schadenfreude machine, taking delight in deflating the egos of New York’s cultural elite, among other, perhaps less worthy, targets.

headline: How 4 Fringe Festival Shows Found Free Rehearsal Space
keywords: ['Theater', 'New York International Fringe Festival', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Artists in the New York International Fringe Festival used their creativity to secure rehearsal locations that wouldn’t break the bank.
lead_paragraph: FOR audiences, the New York International Fringe Festival experience has improved over the years to include some truly civilized amenities — air-conditioned theaters, for one. But artists with shows in the festival, which begins on Friday, still face a perennial challenge: finding a suitable rehearsal space on what is usually a pretty tight budget. Here are edited excerpts from conversations about how four productions made it work this year at no additional cost.

headline: A Shoe Line That Finds Creativity in Flats
abstract: The year-old brand Alumnae, from a Sigerson Morrison founder, offers a host of loafers and slippers in luxe materials.
lead_paragraph: The designer Kari Sigerson is more than just a flat enthusiast; rather, she calls herself a “student of the flat.” In 1991, she launched the brand Sigerson Morrison along with co-designer Miranda Morrison. Now she’s teamed up with Eliza Axelson-Chidsey, another colleague from the label, to found Alumnae, a shoe brand that launched last year. “It’s a celebration of both my and Kari’s wealth of experience designing shoes,” Axelson-Chidsey says of Alumnae. “It’s not an of-the-moment, disruptive type of start-up. Its emphasis is really crafting well-made, wearable footwear” — something not the norm in an industry that has for years been dominated by men fashioning high heels for what the designers call “fantasy women.” “The difference with Alumnae, and of course, Sigerson Morrison, is that we as women can come in and correct our own prototypes on our own feet. We know what we desire and can make it ourselves,” Sigerson says.

headline: British Girl Who Joined ISIS Is Reported Killed in Airstrike
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Terrorism', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Defense and Military Forces']

lead_paragraph: One of the three London schoolgirls who made headlines last year when they fled their homes to join the Islamic State extremist group in Syria is believed to have been killed by a Russian airstrike, a British television channel reported on Thursday.

lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Times reporter Victor Mather describes Olympic TV and the pure joy it provides.
