headline: Mariano Rajoy Fails to Gain Backing for Spain’s New Government
abstract: Lawmakers voted down the plan by Mr. Rajoy, the caretaker prime minister, raising the likelihood of a third national election.
lead_paragraph: Mariano Rajoy, Spain’s caretaker prime minister, failed on Wednesday to gain Parliament’s endorsement to form a new government, raising the likelihood that a third national election would be needed to try to break the country’s political deadlock.

headline: Study Finds Increase in Temporary Paralysis Accompanied Zika Outbreaks
abstract: The analysis adds to substantial evidence that Zika infections — even asymptomatic ones — may bring on a paralysis called Guillain-Barré syndrome.
lead_paragraph: In seven countries that recently experienced Zika outbreaks, there were also sharp increases in the numbers of people suffering from a form of temporary paralysis, researchers reported Wednesday.

headline: U.S. Will Extend HARP Home Loan Program Into Next Year
abstract: The Home Affordable Refinance Program, started in response to the housing crisis, will continue through September 2017 as a new program takes shape.
lead_paragraph: Seven years after the federal government first offered an option to help some homeowners refinance into more affordable mortgages, the program is being extended yet again, and plans for a new refinancing program are being completed.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — “This would be a great place for a date,” said Jack Gleeson, staring at a display of dead fetuses at the Hunterian Museum at the Royal College of Surgeons here.

headline: Donald Trump Gambles on Immigration but Sends Conflicting Signals
abstract: Mr. Trump’s dual speeches in Mexico City and Phoenix were so jarring that his true vision and intentions on immigration were hard to discern.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump made an audacious attempt on Wednesday to remake his image on the divisive issue of immigration, shelving his plan to deport 11 million undocumented people and arguing that a Trump administration and Mexico would secure the border together.

headline: What Colin Kaepernick’s Protest Looks Like to a Black 49ers Fan
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Discrimination', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Football', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'National Anthems']
abstract: A quarterback makes a statement on racial justice, playing for a city that is getting richer and whiter every day.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco — Why are we, as sports fans, continually surprised when one of our heroes turns out to be a real person, with real feelings who is living in the same world we also live in? And when that athlete is black, why does white America respond with anger, as if the hero has broken some kind of sacred rule or understood deal? That deal seems to be, “You just go out and win games, collect your check, and if we really like you, you can retire and sell us stuff in TV commercials.”

headline: Vera Caslavska, Gymnast Who Faced Off With Soviets, Dies at 74
abstract: Caslavska won seven Olympics gold medals as a gymnast in the 1960s. Her public opposition to the Soviet invasion of her homeland, Czechoslovakia, ended her competitive career.
lead_paragraph: Vera Caslavska, a Czech gymnast whose seven Olympic gold medals in the 1960s made her a dominant figure in the sport and whose public opposition to the Soviet invasion of her homeland ended her competitive career, died on Tuesday in Prague. She was 74.

headline: Donald Trump Tries a Jarring New Style: Diplomatic
abstract: In a quick visit to Mexico, the candidate did something he had failed to do in his campaign: communicate provocative ideas with something resembling diplomacy.
lead_paragraph: He did not mock. He did not scold. He did not blunder.

headline: An Overdue Victory for Gay Parents and Their Children
keywords: ['Child Custody and Support', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination', 'ADOPTIONS', 'Editorials']
abstract: New York’s highest court overturned a 1991 ruling denying parental rights to many gays and lesbians, as well as others in nontraditional families.
lead_paragraph: It took 25 years, but on Tuesday New York State’s highest court finally admitted the damage it did in 1991 with a ruling that denied parental rights to many people in nontraditional families — including unmarried opposite-sex couples, stepparents, and gays and lesbians — who are raising children.
